Theres also a nice bouquet of dark fruits and some nice but unexpected floral hops. It is full-bodied and elegantly carbonated. To me this is beer is an utter pleasure; everything about it exudes class. I could see how it may be too sweet for some (if not most) people, but it is a favorite of mine. Excellent.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours translucent amber with small beige head.  Small tight lacing, medium body, and  slightly sticky texture.  Taste is light herbal malt, hint of fruit, and bold  bitter hops.  Not as good as I expected.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, caramel, & some hops; Flavor of slight roasted malt, hops, caramel, toffee, and light fruit; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, I enjoyed it.

British Store, Budapest. Közepesen sötét barnásvörös színe van, habja piszkosfehér színű és rövid életű, laza szerkezetű. Illata malátás, karamellás és aszalt gyümölcsös. Ízében az illatában tapasztalt aromák mellé, gyógynövényes, füves és kissé fűszeres (borsmenta), de édeskés összetevők vehetők ki, a komló éppen csak egy leheletnyi keserűséget hoz ebbe az egyébként enyhén édeskés, erősebb angol főzetbe. Testes, nem túl száraz és szénsavas ale. Tetszett.

Bottle from Alko. 

Pours dark red with a small sticky head. Aroma has notes of malts, caramel and toffee. Taste is quite malty with notes of hops, caramel and exotic fruits. Long lasting, bitter and sticky finish. Okay, quite well balanced.

the liquid is deep amber/reb brown coloured, slightly hazy. pours a pillowy creamy head that settles real nicely and keeps its texture and thickness. aromascape consists of very refined and finely tuned full malts, caramel and toast. has a balanced bitter hoppy side with rich fruit, citrus, herby grass, wood/oak. the taste is very well balanced with an easy bitterness that compliments the light sweetness. seldom does a beer use its alcoholic content with taste this well. it really warms you up and brings extremely deep texture to the tastes and keeps them alive, but manages to avoid being too heavy on the alcohol. its like this beer has a beating heart. tastes with aromas are very easy to pick up and enjoy, just a very full and enjoyable experience. the body is medium full with a creamy and thick texture. carbonation is spot on just to keep things going. this is like the warmer, darker, subtle, deeper and life-experienced uncle of the fullers ESB. nice job.

0,5 l bottle, Csakajosor.hu, Budapest.
Deep mahagony with a nice ruby tone in the body, stable, creamy medium off white head. Toasted cartamel and some herbal hop in the aroma with some plum, light  smoke. Dry taste at the first slip, this herbal hop stays to the end and in the aftertaste, nice fruits and caramel, toasted flavor, light smoke again. Fine!

Szép,rubinvörös amit viszonylag laza nagyobb buborékokat is tartalmazó karamell színű habszőnyeg fed.
Illata banános édesség pörkölt maláta és némi füst. Hátul ott van még egy kis erjedt gyümölcs talán szilva.
Masszív, tartós keserű tengely,  malátás beütés hamuval és kávéval.
Elég jó. Az üveg szép.
Fruity, bitter and slightly sour. Flavorful and complex without affecting sweetness. A wonderful taste experience!

Rich copper garnet pour with two fingers of light tan head. Nose is definitely malt dominant, rich and dextrinous with notes of caramel, raisin, and toasted grain with a mild herbal hop character and fruity notes. A little bit more balance in the flavor, definitely malty but much more of a hop character. Sweet bready malt with some fruity esters and a spicy/herbal hop character. Full bodied with a spicy hop bitterness.

Pours copper-amber with a relatively small off-white head. Nose is sweet and fruity with a little bit of hops and herbs in the background. Flavor is quite well-balanced with a heavy, apple-and-cherry fruit-like malt contrasted against moderate bitter hops. Very sticky and rich. Alcohol (surprisingly, considering the low ABV) comes out just a touch. Good stuff and might be better aged.

500 ml bottle thanks to Nate. Pours a dark copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is certainly like fruit cake, some raisins and alcohol. The flavor is dry caramel and sweet fruity malts, berries and a hint of bitter hops in the finish, lots of flavor, some port like qualities, warm, interesting. A nice brew.

Bottle shared in a train. Clear dark orange pour, thin off-white head that leaves lacing. Aroma is full of floral hops, ripe fruits, some licorice and a hint of grass. Flavor is bitter aged hops and a nice thick ripe fruit malt backbone. Very nice brew.

Bottle: pours a beautiful reddish brown color with aromas of sweet roasted caramel. It fills your mouth with a heavy roasted malty flavor that lingers well after you finish your mouthful. Great beer... Well balanced.
Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown color with a beige head.  Caramel and toffee malt aroma.  Nice flavor with a bit of dry hoppiness in the finish.  Soft carbonation.

Bottle. Rich coppery orange-brown with a slightly tan head. Citrusy, slightly sweet, mix of dark and light fruit aromas.  Some citrus, spice, dark fruit sweetness, but a bit of a toasty malt presence that goes into a dry, fruity finish.  Medium body with solid, but not overwhelming carbonation.  Warming even though its a lower abv.

A near-perfect beer. Incredibly full of flavour, bursting with chocolate, coffee and burnt caramel. This is a pioneering brew which Fullers should be proud of, and it has been copied by brewers around the world. A  bottle-conditioned craft brew long before such things became fashionable. It is perfectly balanced, with a full dark hop flavour which coats the tongue with rich velvety champagne-like texture. A beer without equal, and for me a desert-island beer which I insist that my corner shop has in stock!
Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells earthy with some toasted malt and fruity hints.  Tastes earthy and breaddy with some light fruity hints on the finish.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is biscuit malt, heavy fruitesters, raisin, plum and light alcohol. Flavour is caramel, light alcohol, plum, raisin and fruity notes. Light bitter.

Excellent, excellent beer.  A very difficult beer to dislike, or even find fault with.

Typical english ale malt profile, hops come through a little more, giving a grassy, herbal undertone to a carmel/toffee/spice charactered beer.

The rich copper color is capped by a thick, off-white head.

Aroma is sweet, caramel and spice.  There is an interesting sweet aftertaste, that I can only describe as lingering sweet cream.

Serious English character, serious taste, and a serious beer for serious beer drinkers.  Not a beer to pass up.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with an eggshell colored head. Aroma is very malty, with darkfruit, caramel, buttery notes, fruit cake and some sweet malts. Flavor is again quite malty, with marmelade, buttery and darkfruit, along with fruit cake, caramel and sweet malts. The body is medium with a slightly dry mouthfeel. Overall a pretty nice English Strong Ale, though not as good as their Golden Pride.

Sample from a bottle at St. Louis Microfest 2011. Pours a clear brown color with a foamy off-white head. Aroma of sweet and caramel malts, brown sugar, toast, bread, and dry grains. Flavor largely follows suit, with toffee sweetness, cereal, bread, and grassy hops. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, bready mouthfeel. Not bad but I was surprised to see how highly rated this was. 1845 and London Pride let me down a bit, based on how awesome the London Porter is.

This one is from the Peoria, Illinois International Beer Festival.  Due to lack of space when drinking, my notes wont be that great on these beers.  Aroma was hard to catch - might have had something to do with the area.  The taste was sweet start to finish.  There was a alcohol taste for sure but, it wasnt in your face.

Pours an orangish-reddish brown with half inch head that disappates quickly but leaves a nice layer of small bubbles on top.  Smells of caramel, nuts, and toffee. I can already tell this is going to be a European-style malt bomb.  Taste is distinctly nutty, biscuity, caramelly and sweet.  I detect the slightest hint of chocolate--delicious.  Hops are very mild and earthy.  On the palate this brew really shines-- full, creamy body for a 6.3% ale. Mild carbonation and a lightly bitter finish.  GREAT brew.
From bottle. Nice red-brown color. Strong aroma of hops and malts. Flavor is quite hoppy with nice bitter tones. Aftertaste is powerful and bitter. In next morning I feel this taste also. Great.

Rich honey and malt aroma off a very fluffy light tan head. A reddish brown full-bodied pour, 1845 is sweet, malty, and very smooth. It clings to the glass for dear life, and finishes with a nice bittering hop that is well balanced and very pleasing. Because of the bottle conditioning, I get some yeasty notes, but also some citrus, dark fruit, chocolate and toffee. Very nice! Tasted @ 60F.

50 cl, bottled. Pours clear ruby coloured beer with a beige head. Aroma: Bread, caramel, raspberries, yeast. Taste: Moderate sweetness. Malt, little rye pudding in flavours. Palate: Medium body, little sticky texture, below average carbonation. Bitter finish.

i hope everyone everywhere can get this in 22s. caramel, bread, toast, nuts, floral, earthy, banana, orange, cloudy, hazy, frothy, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter,

Nice brown head.
Nose with fruitcake, prunes and some light liquorice.
Full bodied, nice length, again fruitcake, prune but not so much liquorice, slightly bitter finish.
CVery delicious, but at bit to the heavy side.
UPDATED: APR 7, 2017 This is fantastic stuff. Rich, flavorful, ale-y fruit-y-ness. A little butterscotch. Hop levels were nice. Serving: Bottle

This is such q wonderful completely satisfying beer.  Has to be one of the finest crafted beers in the world.  Rich and malty, but has just enough alcohol to transform this into a very pleasing dry finish that lingers on.  WOW!
Bottle 50 cl. amber with medium off white head. Aromas of dried fruit and caramel. The taste follows the nose. Light sweet flavor followed by a slightly bitter aftertaste.

500mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours vibrant dark mahogany. Woodiness jumps out on the nose, with toffee, burnt caramel and English hops. Flavour matches this almost exactly with the woodiness and hops lingering on the palate. Quite decent.

500ml bottle split with mcberko. Pours a rich dark mahogany with little to no head. Aroma of malts, cherries and also quite sweet. Tastes medium bodied, mostly roasted malts also has subtle flavour of cherries. Finishes quite dry on the palate and leaves a taste of dark chocolate and burnt caramel/toffee. Not bad.

More like an English IPA than an English Strong. Not so complex, but interesting and drinkable. Dark orange/amber colored. White thin head. Aroma is full of malt, sherry-like hints, raisins and other dry fruits, some butter-like hint too. 
Taste is sweet, with a medium body. Not so impressive finish.
Rather good, not excellent.

The beer in the glass is copper brown, slightly cloudy, with a beautiful fine-pored creamy head. The beer smells malty and fruity, especially cherry, also slightly liqueur-like. The beer starts directly with massive malt body, which turns out very roasty. The aftertaste is roasty and slightly fruity, with a light cherry flavor, accompanied by a little licorice. The further course is along these lines: licorice, cherry and roasted malt. All in all, a tasty beer with massive volume!

Bottled 500ml. - from the London Pride store in Ljubljana, shared with Marko. 
Clear amber coloured, medium sized off-white head that went away slowly, malty nutty nose. Slight roasted malt, moderate coffee and nutty with hint of oranges near the finish. Short and pretty empty finish. Pitty for this one. Overrated a lot.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2011 Pours a perfect, beautiful clear red with a foamy, yet creamy, two finger tan head.  Aroma is not very strong, but it is good.  Lots of savory, malty, biscuit smells, as well as a good herby hop smell.  Taste is a very complex of malts, with lots of buttery biscuit flavors, and then the beer finishes with a nice hop bite to clean everything out.  The drinkability of this beer is absolutely insane.  You can polish off a whole bottle in what seems like only a few sips.  This is a very, very, very good beer.
Great dark amber color. The aroma is complex with hints of caramel and licorice. Nice bitterness, a delightful brew.

Finally got to try this one. Bottle from the London Pride store in Ljubljana. Poured a dark amber-red body with a big off white head that went away slowly.  Sweet full malty nose with some dryish bitterness. Coffeish sweet malty, slightly bitter and roasty taste, having some light herbal notes and ending empty. Oh come on, this is ok but nowhere near 3.8!

Bottle at the Spread Eagle, Croydon. It pours a mahogany colour with low carbonation, medium body and a thin beige head. The nose is wood polish, caramel, winter spice, nut and dried fruit. The taste is oak, astringent tang, varnish, fig, plump boozy sultana, cinnamon, nutmeg, dark chocolate, toffee and burnt sugar leading to a smooth light bitter finish. Its an enjoyable and complex strong English ale.

reminds me of a good IPA/ ryePA.

bready, hoppy, malty. good appearance. solid all around.

Half litre bottle, dark ruby colour, tanned head, cloudy. Smelled of smoked coffee with a hint of coriander. Malty, smoky taste. Hints of coffee. Moderate carbonation. Decent winter brew but I expected more.
If you want a beer that tastes like its 13% abv but wont knock you on your ass as much, this is the beer for you.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark red/brown with a thick off-white head.  Aroma of dark fruits, sweet malt, overcooked vegetables.  Flavor of booze, raisin, molasses, and sweet sugary malt.  This is disgusting and undrinkable.  A very disappointing impulse purchase for me :-(
5/4/3/2/8 [2.2/5]
Pours dark brown with a light off-white head. Aroma is fruits and malts. Deep and rich flavor is malts, fruits and hops. Very nice indeed.

50cl bottle. Poured dark mahogany color with a dense head. Aroma is nutty and fruity malty. Flavor is malty, with fruit and  toffee. Smooth. Well balanced, quite dry finish. Very enjoyable tasty beer.
Amber, good head.  Aroma of toasted malt and some hay.  Taste of bread and faint hints of caramel and then some hops bitterness.  A good beer even though its in a style thats not my favorite.

Bottle from: mainbrew.com

Visual: Deep red brown, creamy head, good lacework.

Nose: Toffee, dark crystal malt, mild brittish hops.

Palate: Figs, caramel, toffee, burnt sugar, butter, a small amount of hops, full bodied, and creamy.

Conclusion: A classic strong brittish ale and a great evening beer to be paired with a cigar.
Clear amber with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, dried fruit, malty, caramel and hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and quite bitter. Dry and bitter finish. Very nice. 010211

caramel, floral, hoppy.

Very good beer, similar in style to Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale.

Aroma is rich biscuit, berry and dark fruits, bread. Appearance is ruby brown with small white tan head. Taste is biscuit, bread, berry, plum, caramel, earthy, hint of roast. Palate is medium. Crisp but malty. Overall a tasty beer. Palate is perfect but taste is a little heavy on the biscuit for my liking.

Bottled. Very dark brass colour, with huge beige foamy head. Looks fantastic! Fruity malty nose. Aroma is fruits, malts with plums and raisins and sweet caramel notes. Fruity malty taste, with  ever-lasting bitter hoppy finish. A top one on my list!

Pours amber born with a medium-small head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of caramel and perhaps hint of hops. Taste is malty sweet, some fruityness, caramel and biscuits with a small hint of bitterness into the dry finish. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Very fine beer, excellent strong taste.

Clear deep orange amber with thin off white head. Smells of mild sweet caramels, bready like a graham cracker with its sugar and spice. Taste reveals much more of medium earthy hops after the initial malts and yeasts pass your tongue. some alcohol...flavors are subtle and linger a bit after the finish. lip smacin.  Nice medium body and carbonation. Bitter and dry hops in the finish along with mild alcohol warmth.  Enjoyed the balance of hops, malts, alcohol and carbonation in this brew. not as flavorful as I expected but still very good.

Pint bottle. Chestnut brown with red hues and beige head. Biscuits, bread and raspberries in nose. Complex malty and fruity aroma.,,might be some apricot or peach in there as well. Very malty focussed with some light grassy/hayer hops in finish. Malt is not overly sweet or caramelly - though those characters are there - but is more about dough and toast. Perfect balance. Medium mouthfeel. Great English ale!

Amber, copper and burnt orange in color.  Some dark yellow highlights around the bottom.  Off white, creamy, nicely thick head.  The head really stuck around and had very nice retention.  The aroma came off with some fragrances of alcohol.  Also, got some hints of a buttery note combined with some fruit in the nature of grapes and dried raisin and plums.  Picking up some bread or biscuit malts also.  A lot going on here.  The taste shows the dry breadiness with an alcohol punch.  The fruit sweetens the dryness.  Tastes a bit like a fruit cake.  No bitterness to speak of.  Seems pretty well balanced.  Medium mouthfeel.  Dry and smooth.  Covers the palate decently with a bit of the alcohol warmth.  This beer is pretty good.  Maybe just a bit more of the alcohol flavor than I typically like, but still enjoyable.  Very solid and a good change for me.  I wouldnt mind having this on occasion for sure.

New Beer Distributors, NY 16.9 oz ($5): Pours a darkish amber color with a short-lived creamy off-white head; however, the remnants of said head linger for quite a whiles. Aroma is pleasant, hops are most upfront, followed by an underflying fruitiness. Of course tasty malts are present. Anyway, the taste of this beer is one reminiscent of many IPAs. Hops are a strong force, especially for a British beer, but are very well balanced with the malts. Nicely bitter, but exactly enough that it doesnt impede repeated sips. When I drink beers like this I think that this is exactly what I would a beer to taste, if I were to only have to drink one beer. Quality stuff.
Fine ale. In my opinion, not as good as Fullers ESB but really good anyway.
16th September 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Dark beer. Lots of malt and chocolate but then its followed by bitter coffee which jars. Just a bit too much like hard work.
bottle from Waitrose Sidmouth (2009). Hazy amber colour, large white head. Aroma of hops and port. Full-bodied, malty, dray, hoppy, hints of port wine. Good.
Bottle 500ml. Masterpiece. Aromas of peach, caramel, liquour, oak, and dough. Taste is sweet, with bitter notes, very long length. Palate is creamy, and full bodied. Red, with a frothy white head.

Nice colour, darkish brown with a creamy head. Quite strong at 6.3 but well done not much of an alcohol taste. Slightly sweet, very smooth.
Some people call mash potatoes or chilli comfort food, well if you can have comfort drinks this is it. (for me at least)

Bottle. Clear deep amber with a thick, foamy beige head. Aroma of biscuit dough, herbal hops and caramel. The flavor is more biscuity malt, some fruity yeasty esters, rich caramel and a light hop bitterness to balance the sweetness. Medium body with a mild carbonation and a smooth, clean mouth feel. Great beer that is super drinkbable and packed full of flavor.
Amber wit nice head. Aroma malt, nutty, chocolate. Taste sweet malt balanced with dry hops, chocolate. Medium body, carb average.

Dark reddish-amber color, a minuscule amount of suspended yeast is visible. Frothy two finger head upon pour. Raisins are strong in the aroma, and I may even be picking up some dried apricots. Molasses also makes itself present. Taste reflects many of these, but spices and a biscuity flavor become even more prominent. Medium body, average carbonation and pleasant somewhat bitter finish.
50cl, English brewery, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, clear, good head, good brew
Deep ruby colour with a thick biege head. Aroma is almost caramel like. Rustic, sweet flavour, including caramel and oak. Very nice.
Nice amber colour with light coloured head that quickly disappears. Sweet malty aroma. taste sweet, slightly citrusy, with a light bitter finish. very good.

A: Pours a dark copper amber with a nice two-finger off-white head. Quite a few rings of lacing as it goes down.

S: Strong whiff of caramel malts alongside some initially-unidentifiable spices, almost reminding me of Samuel Smiths Winter Welcome. Somewhat earthy. Hints of orange marmalade. 

T: A nice, brisk hop presence; slightly herbal and earthy. Very nice caramel malt in the background, with a mild amount of spice. Slightly sweet. Still having trouble identifying the specific spicing--perhaps the orange marmalade I detected in the nose.. Mild hints of tobacco and a very slight green apple skin presence. 

M: Medium bodied with a moderate, brisk carbonation. No detectable alcohol presence. Chewy and biscuity.

D: Although certainly not within the English definition of sessionable, this is one incredibly drinkable brew. Nice balance between earthy hops, fruity esters, and caramel malt.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-08-2010

Bottle - Clear copper colour with a good beige head. Low to medium carbonation. Medium body. Caramel malts.  Dark fruits. A little spicy. Touch of alcohol.  Moderately bitter, dry finish with fruity aftertaste. Very nice.

Bottle. Dark amber/ruby with a thick yellowish beige head leaving some lacing. Aroma: malt, toffee, fruit. Taste: toffee, herbs, spices, semi-sweet malt, butter, and also something familiar that is hard to place (I wrote down peppery rum raisin/detergents). Full mouthfeel. Quite a long bitter finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep amber with a large off white, dense head that left a lot of lacing.  Aroma is very malty with lots of caramel and dried fruit.  Flavor follows aroma -- large and round with lots of malt, bread, caramel, dried fruit.  Alcohol is present, but not too powerful.  Palate is thick and a bit oily.  Balance definitely tips toward sweet malt, but the finish has a nice hop presence.  Delicious!

Bottle enjoyed at The Holy Grail in Plano, TX.  Deep amber color with a large lasting head. Aroma is sweet, with notes of caramel, malt and hard candy.  Taste is sweet but not overly so, with a slick, lightly bitter finish.  Really enjoyed this one.
Complex, caramel, chocolate, nuts, fruits?  Enjoyable to drink because of its complexity.
Wonderful full flavor beer, I have found even commercial drinkers of beer like this when I serve it to them - just fresh and lovely.

Pours clear deep dark amber with off white rich head leaving some lacing on the glass. Aroma of sweet melassis, roasted malts, bread, raisins, fruity and spicy tones. Such a "sweet" lean mouth feel. Flavor is slightly acidy, rich malty and hoppy, sweet caramel and fruits. Palate feel is just perfect and finish is first sweet acidy turning into a real biting bitter hoppy, long lived aftertaste.

Bottle.  Pours clear mahogany with a large, frothy and bubbly beige head, long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, caramel, toast), average hops (earthy, spicy, woody), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of plum.  Flavor is heavy malt (bread, caramel, toast), average hops (earthy, spicy, woody), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of plum.  Medium-full body, medium warmth and carbonation, light creaminess with a dry finish.
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 Chestnut colour. White thick froth that stays but leaves lacings. Smells of wood, fruit. Tastes of fruit, hop and bread. Good.

Bottle 500 ml from Terra Vinea in Morteau (F). Dark amber ale with beige foam crown. Fragance malty, hoppy and fruity, hints of licorice and grapes. The taste is malty, deep, full and creamy. There are also fruity, earthy and woody notes, and keys of nutmeg and licorice. Nice hoppy bitterness, also in final, long, complex and dry.
Deep chestnut colour. Nutty and fruity - dried raisins and spicy also. Very pleasant winter beer.
Robust nutty malt aroma. Clear red color with a large tan head. Mild sweet beginning fading to a light bitter finish. Palate is a little light.
Gorgeous beer, tastes sweet and alcoholic, like christmas pudding with a little brandy. Looks lovely in the glass, deep red-brown with a fluffy white head that lasts.

500 ml bottle. Rated @ 24.2.2010.
Pours a clear reddish brown colour with a creamy head. Fruits, citrus and light hops on the nose. Flavour of malts, fresh hops and raisins. Medium bodied with a pleasant mouthfeel. Good brew.

Bottle at Fullers Hock Cellar. Pours a deep amber. Smells of fruit, malt, nut, and oak. Flavor is fruity with caramel malt, spice, and nutmeg. Some light bitterness in the middle. Finish is dry and fruity.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2015 Bottle. Amber body with a fine head. Taste has dried fruits, nutmeg, oak, nuttiness, orange peel, and even some chocolate. Bitter finish. This has some wine-like qualities. A slow sipper. Re-rate: This is a fantastic ale. Due to its wonderful taste, price and availability it has now become one of my comfort beers. Another re-rate: When I think of English ales, this is the beer that I first think of. A personal classic.

bottle.  Dated for june 2010, but 2-3 months cant hurt it too bad.  Pours earthy brown color with visible sediment, and tan head.  Aroma of plum, pear, honey, toffee, spices, oak, caramel, raisin.  Smooth, creamy palate, silky and soft.  Full bodied flavor delivers toffee, caramel, and butterscotch, with indeed a somewhat dry finish.  I found the fruitiness of the aroma to only be barely detectable in the flavor.  There is also an earthy, oaky wood aspect to the taste.  Overall very well done, extremely sessionable and drinkable.  I have loved every beer Ive tried from fullers and this one is no exception.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Bottle. Sweet alcohol, chocolate, fruitcake, dark cherries, spice. Mahogany body, large fluffy off white head. Bitter with sweet notes. Smooth and warming, with a dry finish. An excellent beer, and great enjoyed with rich English food. 9 5 8 4 18 Rerate. Bottle. Pours a reddish mahogany with a large off white head. Aroma is of red fruits, alcohol, rich malt and cherries. Oak and toffee. Pepper, nutmeg and spice. Orange peel, biscuit. Bittersweet. Dry finish. Warming and full bodied. Silky mouthfeel. 9 4 7 4 16 Bottle conditioned. Brown amber body. Medium off white head. Nose is fruit, black malt, hops, spice, fruit cake. Bittersweet with some sour (Brett?) notes. Dry finish. 8 4 8 3 15

Bottle - Best by 21/May/09, ok an extra year of aging. The aroma is a little stale kinda woody. Pours a nice copper/brown with a big off white head, mostly lasting and excellent lacing. The taste is bitter, lots of bite. The body is medium, the texture creamy a touch sticky. The carboantion fizzy and the finish bitter. Not bad maybe sat on it too long.

Medium-dark amber brew with low to medium carbonation. Slightly sweet nutty aroma. Complex flavors with deep roasty malts and raisin notes. Almost smoky, but not quite. Pleasant, clean roasty and balanced finish. This is a top notch beer.

Bottle. Average sized off white dense fomay head (persists) over a dark amber/garnet body. Aroma of dark brown sugar, leather, toasted bread, dried fruits. Taste chocolate, brown sugar with a significantly bitter finish. Medium bodied, smooth, low carbonation.

Bottle. Pours redbrown with a white head. The aroma has got notes of chocolate, hops and rotten vegtables. The taste has got some roasted malt and also some doublebocky rotten vegtable malt. Also some hops and a smokey tabacco like thing going on in the aftertaste. Overall a very complex beer that would have needed a bigger body the get all things togheter. Still quite interesting.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Aroma of malt, vegitables and some hops.
Taste of malt, oak, tobaco and some rosted malt.

pours a clear brown color with a nice thick head and great lacing.  Dried fruit aroma and some decent dark bread notes as well.  Great raisin & dark rye bread flavor.  Its almost addicting.  Overall... a great brew!

Pours out redish brown. Medium sized, pretty good holding head. Sweet fruity smell with some caramel and spices. Seweet caramel and some spices at the taste. Sour-bitter finish after the sweet start. A bit of a disappointment, expected more from this beer.
Murky burgundy colour. Intense woody aroma with lots of dark fruit. Thick, rich texture. Very strong, fruity flavour. Overall its a little too sweet.

She comes in a brown bottle whose cap pops in giddy delight as I take in the sights. Hazy browns under a soft khaki head wink seductively while her head proudly sports a ringlet of delicate bubbles. Treacle, that English sugar concoction for which an inordinate amount of people have no idea what it smells like or tastes like is there in proud standing. Keeping her company are fresh red apples, cinnamon-raisin toast right out of the oven, toffee, and dry nuts in the finish. A breeze of straw and baled hay flitters in the background as a subtle afterthought. I am duly impressed, but I figured I would be. Taking in her aromatics, I dive right into her liquid bounty for a sweet kiss up front with her malt dominating a goodly portion of my first impressions. Grass, straw, and baled hay provide a bitter-dry undercurrent while toffee crunchies and treacle coat my lips and soothe my palate. Her toffee profile is prominent in the middle and back, with a heavier mouthfeel than I was initially expecting. Apples and pears are ripe for the eating, and as I bite through crisp skins, their sweet juices trickle down my throat, melding perfectly with the toffee and treacle for an interesting take on fall candied fruit goodness. Raisin bread adds to her chewy mouthfeel while bitter nuts sneak into her finish; almonds come to mind. Separately her menagerie of flavors would have been a jumble mess, but her palate melded each flavor together in seamless quaffing enjoyment. Where one ended, another one was already beginning, and before I knew it, another flavor was already there making merry and keeping the party going. Well played, and an excellent example of a classic English bottle-conditioned ale that is thankfully easy to find.


Fullers was one of my gateway breweries back in the day. I enjoy them now as I did then, though with a bit more of a critical eye. I cant speak for a few of their other beers over the years, but I can say for sure that their 1845 is still as good now as it was then.

Pleasant bitterness, medium body. From a bottle, a very good beer. Not as good as Fullers ESB (which was from a tap on a beautiful sunny afternoon in San Diego, which probably influenced THAT experience).

Poured from bottle @ sanctuary house.  Malty dried fruit aroma.  Opaque amber in color.  Flavors of malt, nut, molasses , hops.  A bit boozy.  This one is similar to some Belgian brews Ive tried.  Good feel, but became heavy at end.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: In the bottle on 11/13/09. Pours orange with a medium thick off-white head. This is a fairly pedestrian beer. It has a medium hop finish. The flavor has mild caramel and toffee notes. Its ok but nothing special. In fact, I think the regular Fullers ESB is a much better beer.

Appearance - This beer poured a nice amber color with a descent off white.

Smell - Interesing aroma here. Nice smells of fruits and some breadiness.

Taste - Very interesting with a nice breadiness or biscuit like taste to it. The fruit really is present in the taste.

Mouthfeel - A very full and thick body with medium carbonation.

Overall - damn good beer.

500ml bottle.  Appearance is great, pours a lovely hazy dark brown, with an off white head.  Aroma is heavy on the malt, caramel and some spiciness.  Malt and spice on the taste, with a bitter, dry finish.  Has a good body to it, could be a bit thicker.  Really quite nice.
This is an awesome beer.  Great flavors of burnt fruits and malty tones.  Finish is warm and simply amazing.  I love this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2010 Aroma is dark fruits, raisins and roasted date plum. A lot of sweetness in aroma. Taste is again dark fruits, some burnt wood, roasted malts, some chocolate and coffee. Finish is balanced bitterness and sweet.
Pour a ruby red color with a off white head.The aroma is kind of a molasses sent.The flavors are of a blance of sweet malt and bitter hops.The aftertaste is a nice bitterness.Overall a fine ale.

0,5 L bottle. At first aroma is vanilla and a little eggy/skunky but tones down after a while. Not that great.  Looks great with bourgogny color and tan head. Flavor is a lot better then the aroma. Floral bitterness that lingers and give room for dried fruit, caramel, butterscotch and vanilla. Body could be fuller. Still a good English strong ale.
Dry toffee biscuit malt aroma. Dark reddish brown colour. Big roasted malt flavour. Goes down quite well. Not bad but a bit strong for me.

Reddish brown with a beige head that lingers pretty well. Aroma of hazelnuts, dried fruits, toffee, amaretto liqueur, tawny port, Pedro Ximenez and amontillado sherry, sweetshop spices and grass. Taste is sweet with dried fruits, caramel and nuts. A touch of roasted malt and chocolate. Pretty complex malts here. Almost enough balancing bitterness leads to a dryish finish with some earthiness. Very good indeed, but a pint is too much for me - its really rather rich.

Bottle 50cl. Amber brown beer with nice head and good lacing. Smell is caramel and malty. Aroma is amasing on roasted, caramel, malty and chocolate, very long and nice flavor, heavy bitterness on the finish that goes well with an agrume hops character. Quite sweet very creamy, a great beer off course, a good experience, very nice specially the dark chocolate note.

Pours a reddened amber with a big off white to yellow head, which dissipates quickly.  Not much lacing; forms a ring round the glass.  Aroma is woody, hoppy and tart.  There is an earthen presence due to the yeast, but this is not much pronounced.  Beer is slightly oily in the mouth, but quite thin.  Taste is traditional Fullers, malty orange marmalade bitterness, grassy hops, bready with a light alcohol presence.  Finish is a slow bittering that cleans the palate.  This sits between ESB and Golden Pride, or the Vintage beers.  Goes well with a roast.  Its nothing flashy, just a a solid beer.
Tall billowy head. Tan brown. Nutty, toasty aroma. Very malty flavor- coffee, walnut, chocolate. Lightly spicy-tea notes and earth in the finish which lingers very nicely. Impressive ESA.

Bottle from Scotland, thanks Graeme! Pours deep dark clear copper with a big creamy tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and caramel. Taste of raisins, dark roasted malts, maybe some nuts. The alcohol is well hidden, although noticeable . Medium body with minimal carbonation.  Nice deep malty aftertaste. Me like.

50cl bottle: Pours a clear dark brown with a thick white head. The aroma is very raisiny, fruity and malty, a pleasant hint of oxidisation. Full and creamy on the palate, big caramel maltiness, subdued esters with a roasty finish, like a heavier version of a brown ale. Slight alcoholic burn in the throat. Not a lot of hops but a medium, lingering bitterness. Very nice and straightforward ale!

Pours a clear mahogany with thin but firm head. Aroma of dried fruits, yeast, and some distant hops. Flavor was rich in sweet malts, more dried fruits, and a nice hop finish. Very rich in flavor, medium bodied, and a lasting finish. Great beer to sit back and relax with. Well done by an excellent brewery.
Dark brown pour with fairly large beige head.  Sweet malty, fruity aroma.  Seemed slightly sweet at first but then a little bitterness.  OK
Bottle.  Nice dark brown pour with thick, creamy head that lasts.  Nuts, raisin, and caramel.  Slightly sweet and bitter (like sorbitol) and soft on the palate.  Well balanced.  Nice.
Nice reddish orange pour with white head. Nose is raisins and plum. Taste is very nice malts, spiced hops, toffee, caramel and plum. Rated 11/17/2000
red, orange, clear, frothy, tan foam, caramel, citrus, floral, licorice, alcohol, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, lively, long finish, bitter,

Bottle bought at the Kegs and Barrels on 15th in Plano TX and poured into a Trappist glass.

Pours a dark bronze 2 fingers of light tan head.  Smells of plum, malt and a hint of coppper.  The taste is very nicely balanced with toffee, plum and caramel malt with a crisp hop bite on the finish.  Very nice!
Cloudy dark brown, thin tan head. Aroma of fruit, roasted grainy malt, apple tartness. Taste is sweet apple, nut, molasses, toasty bread. Finish is sweet. Thick texture.
Pours reddish amber with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, toast, and light hops. Flavor is malt, toast, nutty, with light fruity notes and a lightly hoppy, dry finish.

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint and a decent sized off-white head. Aroma is of caramel, dark and sweet malts, very slight fruit tint as well. Taste is very well balanced between the hops and malts with the hops winning out slightly in a dry bitter finish. Alcohol is hidden fairly well, not sure what else I can say about this, it isnt amazing, but theres nothing wrong with it, its just good. Guess im not too much a fan of the style.

Bottle 50 cl. Amber, clear with a large but shortlived head. Aroma; Sweet, hoppy with some caramel sence. Taste; More malty, sweeeet with a nice hoppy sence. A bit oily with a mild bitter ending. Good! I think I have become a Fullers fan

500ml from Central Market.  Pours a deep brown body with mahogany highlights.  Aroma is roasty, toasted, toffee, caramel and mildly hoppy.  Flavor is malt forward and toasty with balanced caramel sweetness, some raisin and refined, mild hops toward the end.  Very well done and very easy to drink.

Aroma of sweet malty biscuit and honey, with a note of alcohol.  Pours reddish copper with a foamy head.  Body is full with a creamy texture.  Good hop bitterness that adds complexity.  This is a good beer, it just doesnt seem to come together for me to be a great beer.

500mL bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with suspended sediment and a thin head.  Aroma of caramel and dried fruit with some fainter citrus and pine characteristics.  Pleasantly sweet, with some honey and fruitiness, decently bitter, and a little toast.  Medium bodied, below average carbonation and fairly slick on the palate with a drying bitter finish.
bottle tasting notes from way in the past. sweet biscuit notes with hints of toffee and a slightly holiday spice meld.

Pours a deep amber with moderate beige head.  Very heavy aroma of dark malts (bread, nuts, fruits, caramel).  Intense taste, very well done beer.  Smooth all the way and just a bit of dryness at the finish.  Excellent brew!

I dont dig this as much as when I was 20.  8 years  later its a nice ale anyway.  Complex bottle conditioned ale ,with a big malt profile .  This is an old man beer meant to be drank with a pipe and chess set or some shit.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 500 ml bottle. Finland.
Dark amber colour with small off-white head.
Fruity tea-like hoppy aroma.
Bitter tea-like fruity hoppiness and mild maltiness in flavour. Long bitter fruity aftertaste. Proper strong English Ale. 

Cask at Black Door, Helsinki, Finland.
Clear deep amber colour with small off-white head.
Mild vinegar, alcohol (spirit), malt, caramel, floral hops and some sweetness in aroma. Bitterish floral hops, nuts and wood in flavour. Alcohol kicks in when beer gets warmer. Bitterness stays.

Wonderful English bitter with a well-balanced toasted malt flavor. The liquid is a glowy brown, like old mahogany that hasnt been shined in awhile. The head stays nice and sudsy throughout a glass. The beer definitely gets better as it warms up. I really should have let it warm more before uncapping it, but I just bought it from the grocery store where it was chilled and Im saving the ESB for tomorrow or the next day. Ill sip it slowly. The smell is sweet caramel malt with hops that are very close to just how I picture English hops, refined and bitter. The flavor really brings out a delicious balance of flavors. Its a strong bitter, almost like a weak Old Ale. Lots of big malt notes dominate the palate but the whole package is well-balanced. After so many recent West Coast beers, this beer is like a breath of fresh air or, rather, malt. The feel is sudsy and just a tad watery.

Subdued mellow hops aroma.  Pretty, medium-brown and clear.  Just a shade above root beer.  Substantial off-white head w/ plenty of retention.  Medium-bodied and well-balanced w/ noticeable esters, but a bit thin.  Almost lager-like (not necessarily a bad thing, but not what I was expecting).  Maybe Ill re-rate this one someday.

Bottle.Deep amber with lasting tan head. Sweet and spicey wild honey aroma. Smooth with many solid flavours of xmas pudding, dark chololate and nutmeg. Captivating and sensational beer. Like it very much. Went back to shop and bought three more.

(1pt. 0.9fl. oz bottle - pint glass)  Pours a nearly opaque, reddish brown color.  Has a medium size head, good head retention and leaves a nice lace.  Has a fruity ester aroma and caramel chocolate malt; has notes of butterscotch, licorice and raisin.  Tastes of medium to heavy bitterness, medium sweetness and a light sourness.  Full body, thick texture, flat carbonation and long finish.

Pours dark amber with small off-white head; aroma of red berries, hops, malt; medium to full body, smooth carbonation; flavor is actually quite hoppy based on rich malty backbone including notes of red berries and caramel; the finish has also strong spicy feeling to it. The balance of this beer is again pretty english - which is to say close to perfect.

Cloudy light brown color, not very impressive. The head is thick and creamy, beer is also highly carbonated - bubbles form on the side of the glass and at the bottom.  Aroma is very good - spices, licorice, and rich malt and toffee.  The taste is similar - robust and full bodied with a sweet and spicy finish that lingers on the palate.  Sticky texture.  Imagine drinking this one next to the fire in a nice English Pub on a cold Winter night.....
After all the hype it was a disappointment. Expected more. deep red clear colour. white head.

Bottle.

A - Deep red-orange amber color. Decent sized, bubbly and foamy head that is a light beige ivory color. A little below average retention with almost no lacing left.

S - Good amount of toasted caramel malt, as well as some bready smell. Also some general fruitiness with apple and some orange being the strongest.

T - A lot of bready malt taste with some caramel and grain taste too. Some earthy hops along with a bit of floral hops as well. Also a fair amount of gold fruit (good amount of apple and orange). Sweet base and good amount of malts throughout., but fair amount of hop bitterness and fruity tang balances it out. Just a hint of alcohol taste is present.

M - Medium body with moderate carbonation. Rich and smooth and a bit creamy.

D - Easy to drink with great mouthfeel that goes down easy. Rich and full flavors with a good balance of malt/bread taste and some hop/fruity tang.

Notes: Really good beer that is full of English hops and bready malts as well as fruit. Really nice mouthfeel and flavors. Might get a little bready but well balanced beer. I would definitely recommend this.

Ladies and gentlemen this is beer with a malt backbone. Pours the most beautiful amber copper tone, with a deep thick head. Tight carbonation. Aroma is earthy, fruity and.....malty! This is a heavy beer with not much in the hop area. Not as balanced as far as hops and malt, but good nonetheless.

Deep amber/brown color with sticky, lingering head. Aroma is fruity, chocolaty malt. the taste leads with some hop bitterness but is very malty, chocolaty follow through with some lingering bitterness and a fruity aftertaste.

Bottle pour from Pound and Pence. Reminded me of a light barleywine. A sweet, malty aroma gives way to a nicely balanced malt character with strong, darkly fruity notes and a touch of hop bitterness on the tail. Medium in body and nicely carbonated. Not a sessioner - unless youre pretty hardcore. Tasty and a dynamic beer.

Tall creamy off white head, clear amber body, aroma is distinctly sweet and fruity apple juice, caramel, mild roast, maybe a hint of tobacco, flavor is bold, initial flavor is all malt, caramel, mild rye spice, husk, mild roast, leads into dark fruit, raisins, figs, huge malt flavors are balanced very well against some piney noble hop bitters, mild diacetyl, tasty stuff! Extremely well balanced

Bottle. Dark amber colour with a thick, creamy and lasting off-white head. The aroma sweet, caramel malt. The flavour is soft, sweet and malty with a bitter finish. Aftertaste is filled with fresh bitterness and it lasts long. Very tasty English strong ale.

500ml bottle from the LCBO. Pours a reddish-copper color with an ample tan head that has plenty of lacing and fades slowly. Aroma is moderate in strength and illuminates raisins, malts, almonds, anise and toffee. Flavor pretty much mirrors the aroma. Mouthfeel is a touch thin up front but rounds out to a nice satisfying fullness, the carbonation is light but adequate. Finish is dry and earthy with just a touch of hops and some lingering caramel sweetness. Overall this is a superbly crafted beer.
50 cl bottle. Clear dark amber body with tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and hops.

~Aroma of caramel, biscuit, nut, dried apricot, and toffee.
~Pours a clear dark red color with creamy off white head.
~Caramel and biscuit malt flavor with dried apricot near the finish, some nuttiness.
~med to full bodied with med CO2, malty sweet dry finish.
~I think my bottle may have sat on a warm Bevmo shelf too long. Still enjoyable malty English ale. Probably much nicer if better kept.

Pours a clear dark amber. Frothy head going to a nice lace. Aroma of hops malt fruit caramel.Taste of malt fruit toffee caramel yeast lesser note of chocolate. Medium carbonation. Somewhat bubbly mouth feel. Medium body. Bitter spicy resin dry finish. This is a quality brew with a lot of character. After warming up and airing out in the glass it really comes alive. But in the end it was a little bit to bitter to become one of my own personal favorites.
From a bottle poured a brown/amber color with a small head.  Bitter malty flavor with a lingering finish.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2011 Poured 500ml bottle in pint glass - small beige and thick head, maybe one finger, very little carbonation with nice lacing; nice rich mahogany color with slight haziness; roasted malt and sweet aroma with hint of figs or dates; medium body creamy texture; excellent balance with touch of bitterness against a wonderful toffee flavor and slight hint of smoke; smooth lasting finish to dry and hoppy; fabulous beer!

Pours clear, dark coppor color with unusually thick white head. Bubbles are very fine and lace is good.

Nose has a fruitcake aroma. Miscellaneous baked desserts with something sweet, but hard to identify.

Palate is caramel sweet at first, moderate hops to balance, and carries through with an overcooked biscuit taste.

Finish is dry and long, hoppy.

Rather than use pretentious terms to describe this beer, or quote the BJCP guidelines, Im just going to say that this beer has the power to restore your faith in mankind. The fact that something of such incredible quality and attention to detail is still being produced in this age of cheap and good enough is indeed worthy of the highest praise.

If you are mad about cascade hop-bombs, this will not be for you but I encourage you to try it anyway. It is truly one of the eight or ten finest beers on earth.

500ml bottle. Pours a plentiful lasting head , aroma of boxed chocolates , the colour of body like an aged pecan shell. I noticed spices immediately on the mouthful with some fruit like tart , medium bitter roast on aftertaste.

1 pt. 0.9 oz bottle with a best before date of 6/16/10. My very first impression as I sniffed the opened bottle was straight tobacco. It is chestnut in color and to be honest it doesn;t have a great head but it does have good lacing, maybe my glass wasnt perfectly clean. It smells and tastes quite malty, some bready fruitiness, very robust flavor.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-25-2010 02:50:46
fantastic beer, hugely warming flavour, malt character is what this beer is all about! hints of raisins, plum and all things fruit cake....
This is a big beer.  From the monumental head to the big deep raisens and plums.  It is epic... as they say.

Aroma of dark chocolate, caramel, spiced rum and cherries. Appearance is dark red with tan head. Flavor is the epitome of English beer: Defining caramel malt backbone, but with a chocolate cherry rum twist. Palate is creamy and the finish abrupt. My favorite English beer.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2010 The nose is all spice, fruitcake, even a touch of brandy. Very little head, but the color and mouthfeel is elegant. The flavor is a neat mix of bitter and sweet, with a faint savory overtone -- roasted grain, perhaps, or rye bread. If this is what bottle-conditioned ales are about, then I am on board.

Pours dark copper color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits and caramel. Flavors of raisins, toasted malts, nuts and iced tea. It has an off tasting medicinal aftertaste. Medium body with minimal carbonation.

@ Kickbacks Gastropub Jacksonville, FL. A whopping $9 bottle of beer. They are getting ridiculous with the prices on brew. I suppose the masses have caught on.  The beer pours a nice dark amber. Head blows up like Hiroshima and the winch @ the pub made sure that I knew so. It was all head.  Beer has a decent nose. English hops and malts, and a nice bitter grain. Taste is solid grains, mild hops, and burnt malts.  Some spices, however not overwhelmingly. Subtly played, and in favor. Decent brew. Not sure id drop $9 on t his again, nor $12 on the Vintage ale.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Bottle, thanks to TheJester. Brown/amber pour with a medium rather creamy white head. Aroma is mellow. english malts, toffee caramel and a little hops. Taste is very mellow as well, good sweet/bitter balance. Not a favorite for me but pretty good.

Lovely rich amber colour. the aroma is classic English ale with rich caramel malt and some earthy hop characteristics. Full bodied palate with some slight sweetness. Caramel malt with some slight roastiness and great hop balance. A beautiful beer, very enjoyable to drink, bit of a special occasion beer. Love it!

Dynamite reddish-amber hue shows off gorgeous foam cap!  If the appearance doesnt impress you, just smell it!  Warm, spicy notes - nutmeg, allspice - expertly showcases the yeasts fruity esters.  EKG hops - a standard for this style of beer - are expertly showcased in a way that aroma AND flavor all come together in a symphony of balance!  No, I do not work for the brewery - Im just happy to find a brew that so well defines the best of its intended style!  Fantabulous

Pint bottle into an English pint glass.  Pours amber/red with a thick and tight khaki head.  The aroma is dusty malt with a hint of sour fruits.  The flavor is minerally hard water and metal with malty bitterness, lots of biscuit, some citrus, and a chocolatey finish.  The mouthfeel is big and creamy and the glass is covered with lace.

Dark reddish with a small off-white head. Aroma is extremely balanced from juicy malts and grassy hops. Flavour is fairly intense with notes of biscuits and light dried fruit acompanied by grassy refreshing hops leading to a fairly dry and juicy finish. Body is medium and fairly smooth.

Gorgeous ruby pour.  I dont use the word gorgeous lightly, and it most certain applies in this case.  Heavy smell.  Loads of plum, fig and raisins on the nose.  Some sweet notes of grape juice as well.  Lovely. Dry mouthfeel that carries a chalky taste of dark fruit.  Has a dried fruit taste, as of freeze dried fruit and trail mix. After taste has a little taste of roasted malt but not much.  This is pretty good.

Half-liter bottle, Best Before 24/Oct/08. Rating #1845! What? I couldve had a Minhas Craft 1845? Oh, wait, Im not near a 7-11. So lets pop this. Pours a nice brown body with a light brown, big head. Sweet, alcoholic smell, notes of whipped caramel. Taste is malty, yet a little drier than its smell. Suggestion of dates and walnut in the malt roast. Solid, earthy English hops. Alcoholic impressions are gone once I start tasting. Solid, pleasant English ale, not as "big" as the style suggests, but it is stronger than a seesion draught.

500ml bottle served in my 22oz snifter. Clear garnet pour topped by a thin beige head. Smells of apple peel, toffee, chocolate, and a nondescript fruitiness. Tasting notes of prune, toffee, fig, nuts, and that fruitiness from the nose. Bitterness is apparent but not overpowering. Remains dry throughout. Quite complex for a mere 6.3% abv.

Pours a pale copper/ruby with a large persistent head leaving lacing down most of the glass.
Rich aroma of spiced marmalade, dried figs, golden syrup, well-aged sherry, some woody notes and earthy English hops. Lovely, reminds me of plum pudding.
More oxidised alcohol is noticeable upon tasting, though more like a port than sherry. Hints of oak shine through what is quite a rich combination of treacle, caramel and nutty malt. Sharp alcohol on the finish detracts somewhat from the overall experience.
All this is supported by a full, rich body and low carbonation, which suits the beer well.
Cloudy dark amber with a foamy cream head.   Nuts, roast, chocolate and dark malts on the nose.   Nice on the palate with a nutty chocolate flavor and a roasted finish.

Bottle. Poured a darker amber color with a littlewhite head that left some lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma was yeast, caramel, and fruits. Flavor was fruits, bread and malts. Medium body. Very good beer.

Mahogany reddish colour with a tall and handsome head leaving a neat lacework. Very, nutty and fruity aromas. Dry and hoppy ale with a long, bitter aftertaste. Typical notes of nuts and caramel. Pleasant

Bottle: pours. Clearish chestnut brown with a large off white head that last with great lacing. Aroma has a good caramel malt and a some toasty old bread aroma. Also some english hops that seem to be fading. Very small amount of fruity esters. Flavor is a bready dry toast flavor some decent caramel   Hop bitterness plays well with the beer.

Bottle 10 C,2009-08-03
AP: dark amber, beige nougat head
AR: suryps bread + little bit of alcohol
F: suryps bread, plum (maderia)
AF: calm after flavor
OBS! warning sour resedue
Nice color, great tasting ale.  Almost had a chewy, unfiltered feel on some mouthfuls.  Somewhat hoppy, but nothing overwhelming.  Solid performer.

tasting sample on 11/5/09...  pours a light red / orange with a small off white head... some apple and light hops on the nose... medium body with more apple, some grapes, caramel and a touch of spice.  sweet finish.

I was not overfly impressed with this beer.  It had a very sour malt flavor that was overly evident.  The alcohol was not hidden like some other posters claimed, though it was alos not overbearing.  The color was much more cloudy that I hoping as well.  Overall, I found it to be rather average.

500 ml bottle from Total Wine in Tustin ($3.49).  Pours a lovely deep brownish ruby color with one finger of off-white head.  Aroma is full of sweet caramel and sweet fruits (overripe plum, berries, and a hint of citrus).  Taste is mildly sweet with toasted malts, rich fruit, spice (nutmeg, yes), and a certain earthiness.  Finish is noticeably dry with a bit of citric hops emerging in the end which takes an edge off the sweetness.  Great aroma, good flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 50cl dark brown bottle, as pictured.

Pours a perfect, clear mahogany with a big, frothy beige head. Good retention, plenty of lacing. 

Aroma of roasted malt, toffee and ripe plums. Body is a little lighter than that of "Golden Pride" and "Vintage Ale", but ultra smooth, with low carbonation. Oily mouth feel. 

Complex taste of caramel, coffee, and dark fruit, but with a compensating note of dry hops that quickly negates the initial sweetness. Gets more bitter as you keep drinking and the beer warm up a little. Dry, hoppy finish and lingering, medium bitter after taste. Despite the increased abv, there’s no real alcoholic note to speak of. Smooth!

Another superbly balanced and eminently sessionable brew from Fuller’s (I must get around to visiting their Chiswick brewery next time I’m in London), with sweet and bitter notes superbly complementing each other. A wee heavy winner in the strong ale category. Drink irresponsibly!

Pours a fairly transparent brown with a gorgeous frothy head and very nice lacing. Aroma of bitter malt, nut, and hop- subtle, but nice. Flavor is delicious- a tad bit thin, but really smooth. Excellent stuff.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours a copper red with a small head and an aroma of raisins, sweet malts, syrup, caramel and some bitter hops. The flavor is sweet, mainly malty with notes of raisins, vanilla, honey, caramel, ripe fruits, ontbijtkoek and mybe some cream. A nice hoppy finish. Good but a bit too expensive for me.

Bottle. Colour... golden-orange with a thick head. Nose... sweet malt, toffee and Christmas cake. Palate... gently carbonated, plenty of toffee, treacle sirup, delicate hops, dates and a lengthy finish.
Good looking amber color with a nice head. Flavors of bready malt and a nice bitter hop complex.

( 16.9oz bottle with best by date of 3/10/10) pours clear brownish-red with nice creamy/oily head and nice creamy lacing. Nose of caramel, toasted malt, and sweet bread. Taste is nutty, roasted malt, light and very well balanced English-style hops. This beer achieves a superb balance between hops and malt. Nice!

The linger is a little too roasty but it is a very small complaint.

Part of my low rating for this ale is my fault--Im not a big fan of English & Belgium ales.  That being said, however, I dont believe in relative rankings: a beer is either good or it is not.  This ale is not the best.  I need to stay away from these infernal English & Belgium ales.
Deep amber color with a small tan head. Malty and funky aroma lead to a nice dry crisp taste, kind of like an ESB but bigger. Nice lingering flavor of sweet malts, but still dry. Very Good.
A nice rich flavor, boisterious in color and aroma. Distinctive, bold aftertaste and a gorgeous whipped caramel head. Good with desserts for its consistency.

It poured a lightly brown dark golden liquid with a big lasting foam, that left allot of lacing. It had a smell of caramell and something funky like an outdoor toilette. It had a smooth mouthfeel at first but got stingy further back in my mouth. It tasted of caramell, malt, some roasted notes and funky toilette. Not very good.
Dark amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of malt, bread and bisquit. A flavor of bitter, malt, caramel and sweets.

500ml Bottle - Copper with red tinges and a tan head. Fruity and malty aroma with raisins and marzipan. Rich, fruity and vinous taste with hints of alcohol, raisins and fruitcake, followed by a bittersweet finish.
Lots of licorise and dark fruit throughout. Perhaps not in 100% condition this bottle, but still showed a lot. QUite rich and probably a one bottle drink on a nice chilly evening.

Nutty, bread aroma and looks like a dark amber/light brown color with superb head retention and lacing. Flavor of standard ales, with notes of malty goodness and a strong hoppy finish. Uneventful palate and overall this is a pretty good ale that ill hopefully gain a better taste for. Cheers!
bottle. Deeper copper pour. medium malt richness 7 hints of ok. osk presence increasing at beer warms up. rich caramel malts, very good
A light brown beer with a decent head. The aroma is malty, & caramel. The taste is very smooth nutty, malty, caramel & is one of the smoothest beers Ive had.
Deep brown pour.  Sweet malt aroma.  Nice malty taste.  Not much in the way of an aftertaste.
Bottle. Amber pour with a thin white head. Watery , as I have come to expect.  Flavor is mild, sweet and malty:  Lightly bitter finish. Satisfactory.

Bottle. Another winner from Fullers! Pours a lovely golden copper with an off-white head that lasts well. Nose is packed with notes of toffee, rum, golden syrup, banana and malt. Very smooth mouthfeel with flavours of caramel, brown sugar, malt as well as a very nice bitterness that blends very well with the sweeter notes, although the beer isnt as sweet as it sounds. Very nice indeed.

500ml bottle. Dark copper rusty vcolour with a deep thick dense beige cap of foam. Aromas of malt and spiced fruit tantalise the nose. Strong flavour with a medium bitterness and a strong bitter acrid aftertatse that isnt unpleasant.

Nice label.  Dark amber pour.  Yeast and malt aroma.  1845 is a well balanced and flavorful English ale.  English hops and yeast are front and center.  The finish is sweet and hoppy.  Another nice brew from Fuller.
English like flavor with this beer with the water and the grassy hops and the toffee like malts that pattern all around it.  strong flavor. funky aftertaste that does work but the rest is wonderful.
Amber pour with a thin, soapy white head. Aroma of malt and some mild Goldings. Flavor is mild and malty: sweet, subtle pale malts. Lightly bitter finish. Nice.

Nice soft aroma of hops and some barley, but also wateriness. Looks great, nice fluffy head, nice amber-brown colour. flavour is a simple barley and hops combination, some caramel in there, but not very complexing. Very refreshing, however, feels good on the mouth.

Bottle. Has that ripe flavour you expect from a beer of this type. Initially, I would say that it verged on the stale, but the flavour develops on the tongue and is full of rich berries. Deeply red and pleasing, another one to savour.......

Aroma is nice, malty, bready, with notes of fruit, toffee, and unexpectedly, a bit of chocolate.  Appearance is very attractive, semi-opaque, red/brown, thick off-white head.  The flavor is fruit, bread, toffee, very bready, very good.  Again a slight bit of chocolate. (?1?) Finish starts malty sweet, seques into a strong floral hop bitterness.  Excellent.  Mediium/thick mouthfeel.  Very nicely crafted all ther way around.

Cockney Pub, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled, 230809.
Amber with off-white head. Aroma of malt, yeast and dried fruit. Flavor is caramel, hop spice and red berries.

Bottle. Good looking beer, reddish brown, with an off white head. Malty yeasty aroma, taste starts sweet with dough and hints of raisin, and moves quickly to a tight bitter finish that stays around a while.
A really good strong ale, it is even nice to look at in the glass, with its dark colour and creamy head.  Fair bit of malt in the aroma and in the taste, but not overpowering.  Liked it a lot!

(bottle - 500 ml) Rich copper pour with a thick off-white head. Aroma if full and fruity with hints of raisins, plums, spices, and some cinnamon bread. Flavor is dark and spicy at the beginning with a serious malt bite as soon as you drink it. A hoppy bitterness comes at you in the middle with hints of plums and yeast. Finishes bitter and lightly spicy. Very smooth with a lingering finish. Quite nice.

Clear brown to orange, thick pillowy beige head. Earthy aromas of dark fruit, hearty bread and a malt sweetness. Light toasted malt flavor gives way to a gentle caramel and floral hops. Perfectly balanced by a crisp, spicy bite. Finish battles between a malt and hops.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Re-rate 11/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at Naamas place. Thanks Vova. Best before 4/10. Aroma is malty, oxidized, with lots of dark chocolate, nuts and some fruitiness. Sweet oxidized flavor with malt, chocolate, a bit of caramel, nutty notes, a touch of cardboard and some fruitiness. Medium-bodied. Decent. 7/3/6/3/13=3.2

Re-rate 11/7/11: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks tomer. Malt, caramel, honey, fruits, a bit of graininess and a bit of hops. 5/3/5/3/10=2.6

Re-rate 7/24/11: Bottle sample at a Fullers tasting at Porter & Sons. Deep red-amber with a beige head. Aroma of lots of malt, caramel and fruits. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, honey, some toastiness, fruits and a drier finish with some slightly earthy  bitter hoppiness and a bit of alcohol. Medium-bodied. 6/4/6/3/12=3.1

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks zvikar! Deep red-ruby color with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, light smoke hints and earthy hop notes. Sweet and malty flavor with biscuits, some fruity notes and a bitter finish with nice British earthy hops. Medium-bodied. 6/4/7/3/14=3.4

(bottle) Dark Brown clear with medium off white creamy head. Smell is brandy  rich fruit, malty and a little fresh hops. Taste is a beautiful rich balanced things, fruit cake and toffee. Sweet biscuity malt and a little bitter hops. Warming alcohol with a smooth easy drinking texture. Some tiny coffee notes. Very nice a great english ale.

500ml bottle. Rich, malty aroma. Mahogany with off-white long-lasting head. Flavour is burnt caramel with hints of spiciness. Very malty palate with hoppy bitterness. Finishes with rather astringent hoppiness. Very enjoyable beer, miles away from the bland macrobrewery slops.

Pours a deep amber, almost clear dark brown, with medium off-white head.  Aroma very malty, dried fruit, decent hops, dry roasted nuts, and a bit of chocolate.  Flavor matches well and comes together nicely to make for a very enjoyable brew.  Very nice stuff.
Rich copper red.  Nose; bready, apples, dried orange peel, very complex.  Flavah; sharp bitterness, heavy especially in the finish. Dried fruit are prdominant.  Should let warm.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2011 At a tasting, thanks Tomer, pours red to orange hazy and stunning with a decent head, aroma of yeast, malt, honey, marmalade, vanilla and wood, flavor is bitter with agrapefruit skin, tangerine and malt, medium bodied, nice.
Thanks Naam, Deep red with nice cream color head, aroma of malt grapes, nuts, dry fruit, chocolate and some whiskey, flavor is dry with malt, chocolate, nuts spiced with Cinnamon and clove, complex yet balanced with some bitter smokey finish. Full body, I like the style and the beer.

Heavily Enjoyed this brew, I have to travel 300 Kms to pick one up but well worth it in the end. Very Rich and aromatic Pleasant drinking both as a slow sipping beer and a session. Not your typical session albeit but one I would enjoy.

Bottle (500). Poured hazy burnt ruby with a huge lightly tanned, creamy head which lasted superbly. Aroma was of earthy hops with orange peel, toffee malts, red berries, 5 spice, caramel and hints of fennel. Flavor was a good rustic/earthy hop bitterness with toffee malts, juicy gooseberries, figs, black pepper and a very dry woody finish. Noticeable alcohol content. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation, a dry mouthfeel and a superb length finish. Very well crafted English Strong Ale from Fullers  perfect full-bodied winter warmer.

This in The Netherlands not much seen beer has a characteristic smell coming of the small head. Typically English I presume. Smell is hoppy, taste is dry, mouth feel is thin. A long and fine bitter after-taste. Overall it has a bit of a poor palate. With British Pound on an all time low, still very expensive beer though.
Very good.  Pours light amber with a small head.  Very sweet flavor.  Very drinkable.  Would definitely drink again.

Bottle from Waitrose.Attractive reddish-amber colour with a lbeige head. It has a toasty aroma with a hint of caramel, yeasty earthiness and light goldings. Complex flavours develop as the beer warms up.. Good, robust ale...perhaps not as good as when I first had it but still of a standard that Fullers seem to have let drop in recent years in most of their other beers.

So glad i found a bottle of this. A reddish brown coloring was topped by a magnificent head in my glass mug. Lots of sweetness comeing off the smell that reminded me of berries or mellon. malty taste with a bit of yeast and just a kiss of bitterness in the end. a dry finish makes me bring the mug back for another sip every three seconds. If you see this, buy it.

Pours reddish brown with an uneven, pillowy, offwhite head.  Head is long lasting with good lacing.  Taste is caramel, malty upfront with a superb, long lasting dry finish.  Drinkable, subtle, and immaculate.

Pours brick red with a beige head.  Looks amazing in the glass.  Fruit, sweet malts, some caramel, toasty, some whiskey, oak, and light spicing.  Medium, smooth body.  Flavor is full of spices, caramel, toasty malts, dark fruits, alcohol, and light roasted malts.  Finish is somewhat bitter with alcohol noticeable.  Very drinkable even at 6.3%.  Fantastic.

Fullers 1845 is a pretty clear, reddish brown ale with a dense, yellow elastic head that has great retention and lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet with funky malt and cave-like smells, fresh grain and chocolate.  Its quite full bodied and very smooth with a crisp, dry finish.  It has an excellently balanced taste.  The flavors are very fused.  Theres a touch of roast and a lot of malt thats not really sweet nor dry.  Dried fruit, like prune, is apparent.  The aftertaste is slightly bitter with wood resin and juniper.  What a classic!

Pours deep red/brown with a nice, very slowly diminishing tan head. Sweet aroma of malt, fruity with notes of caramel and goldings. Medium bodied, with a roasty taste of caramel malt and dark fruits, leaving a long lasting, sweet and bitter aftertaste. Medium bodied, with little carbonation.

Source:Bottle at the brewery. 
Glass:Taster glass. 
Appearance:Clear red/brown pour with a two finger off white head.  
Aroma:Caramel malt with grass, dark fruits and a hint of citrus. 
Flavor:Caramel, dark fruits, a hint of smoke and a decidedly floral, bitter finish. 
Palate:Medium/full body with solid carbonation.
Overall:Really enjoyed this.  Was surprised with the complexity of the flavor.

Pours a clear mahogany, with a 3 finger chunky, tan head that has great retention. Aroma is caramel, planty hops, fresh grain, cereal grain, fresh red apple, sweet grass, straw, dark fruit, pitted fruit (notably nectarine), a little toast, a hint of citrus potpouri, and lots of earth notes. Flavor is grainy malt, grass, planty hops, dark caramel, some raisin, randomly wooded campfire smoke, sweet tobacco, burnt orange peel, spicy/planty hops, cinnamon, green maple wood, and floral hints. Finsih is bitter hops, roast, light pine, woody and light earthy notes. Palate is medium body and dry from entry through finish with a lighly bubbled, yet sharp carbonation. Really a fantastic beer that (tin my experience, at this point) deserves its throne atop the "English Strong Ale" ladder. Great stuff.

medium to dark red with large white head.  moderately low carbonation  nose of dark crystal malts.  flavor starts with mild hop bitterness followed by a noticeable hop flavor then some upper lovibond crystal malts that give it a raison-like flavor, some residual sugar provide some sweetness and depth and some fruity esters.  a great beer, not sure what style you would call it, not hoppy enough for a bitter and not malty enough for a barley wine

500ml bottle into pint glass. A red-orange beer with a fluffy beige head providing good lacing down the glass. Noticeably malty nose with notes of dark dried fruits and warming spicy hops. Chewy malt driven palate with a nicely balanced dry fruity hop bitterness to the finish. Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel and thickish texture for the style. A excellent refined bitter well worth seeking out.

clear amber, giant thick light brown head.
hoppy and slightly citrussy aroma.
sweet, malty, caramelly, slightly dry flavor. sweetness and slight bitternes in the flavor lingers for long after youve sipped. very tasty and because of the dry hops, also quite drinkable almost quenching.
bottle 500ml, dark colour, strong aroma, full of flavor, spicey, a little bitter, very very good.

Colore rosso scuro ma vivo,schiuma beige chiaro cremosa e persistente.Laroma è leggermente amaro, acido e lievemente maltato.Il gusto è amaro inizialmente e nel lungo finale con in mezzo sentori quasi floreali.Corpo asciutto e cremoso.Una ale davvero molto buona.
I was pretty amped to give this one a try.  Poured amber with a tan head.  Caramel and malt aroma with a malty caramel taste.  Somewhat bitter.  Not as good as I expected.

From the bottle, it poured clear rich amber color with fluffy tan head, good retention. Sweet caramel aroma with some alcohol. I get a very bready, pastry crust flavor, some warm roasted bitterness. A delicious English strong.

Cloudy reddish amber with medium beige head. Rotten vegetables hit my nose along with some bloody awfull malts. Flavour was sweet with malt, caramel and floral hops. Had some earthiness to it. Mild bitter stuff.

Poured a dark copper color with minimal white head.  Taste is excellent with a slightly fruity aftertaste and smell.  This is definitely my favorite English Strong Ale, and one of the best Fullers brews.

Rating Nr. 800. Bottle. The aroma is light bitter, light sour and malty, also flowery. The head is small, light beige and creamy with a normal duration. The body is clear, dark red and lively. The first taste and the finish is quite bitter, the middle part is more flowery. The finish is very long. The beer has a normal carbonation with a medium strong body and is dry and creamy. A very nice Ale.

What a gem of a beer. Beautiful spicey malt profile thats about as good as any Ive ever had. Wet bulging over ripe dark fruits balanced out by pepper and earthy notes like nutmeg and hot honey. Tons of flavors floating around in this one, and that soft bouquet of hops thats behind all Fullers beers is very potent in this one. A great beer.
Bottle. Pours amber with a creamy head. Roasted malt, caramel, dried fruit, nuts and earthy hops. The malt is well balanced with a clean hoppy finish. A delicious beer.

Bottle - Pours deep, cloudy amber with a nice frothy head. Aroma is wonderful, with caramel, sweet malt and a nice smooth bourbon. Taste doesnt quite pack the punch of the smell. I get roasted malt with caramel and toffee notes. The malt is a little off, as theres some bitterness that kind of comes in waves. Its hard to describe, but its not as smooth as it should be. This is pleasant to drink and nice and creamy. I wasnt super-excited to pull this out of the cellar, but it exceeded my expectations.

The aroma is sweet with caramel, yeast, fruit, and grassy hops. The appearance is amber with a large foamy head. The flavor is like the aroma with a bitter sweet finish. The palate is OK for the style. Overall a good beer but not great.
Just a great English ale.  Could drink this one all day (or all night).  Always a good standby since its so widely available.

Bottle. Clear deep amber body with a nice creamy tan head. Lots of malt in aroma with some nutty character. Notes of caramel and dark fruits but also some rotten vegetable. Heavy malty flavour with lots of caramel and a little smoke. Lovely creamy palate.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Damn, smells almost like a sour ale with a bunch of nuts added.  Great flavor with a very yeasty, nutty finish.  An incredibly original and complex brew.  Really dug it.

At 6.3% some may feel this ale is a bit strong. However it has a great taste and is a very good ale, as you would expect from Fullers. Very drinkable and it is ashame is not available on draught often, generally sold in bottles.

From a bottle at the brewery tap:

Deep brown with a lovely head.

Cow manure and deep blue cheese notes. Some light freshness in the form of rustic pears.

Rich and boozy, barnyards and Gruyere in the mouth.

Thin and a bit of a strange one this. I wouldnt necessarily choose to have it again.

A nice beer from Fullers, too bad it went out of sale here. Cant see any reason for it, this is one of the most consistent british ales around. Fruits and nuts in the aroma, dry nutty hoppy taste with some sweetness thrown in. Works for me and was one of the first good things I tasted that got me into beer in the first place.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 16.9 ounce bottle from WIne Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear red color with a large frothy head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma of grain, nuts, caramel and tart fruit notes. Taste is bitter hops, caramel, grain, nuts. Medium bodied.

Average size tan head atop a garnet body that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma of soft fruit, bready malts and yeast.  Earthy taste, some sweetness, mild nuttiness, but well balanced by fragrant, floral hops. Very smooth mouthfeel, gently carbonated, with a dry, long lasting finish.  Complex, but extremely drinkable.

Pours a really nice copper color with a long lived white head.Aroma is hoppy with a big malt undertone.  Some fruit and maybe a little Cinnamon?  Clove?  Flavor is very fry, some gof hop bitterness, but then a big malt character as well.  There was something really kind of odd and metallic in the backend though.  A bit off-putting.  Pretty decent beer if it wasnt for that metallic twang.

Bottle from Tesco. Copper coloured beer from my native west London. Malty, caramel, fruity, spicy, almost like a light English Christmas cake. This is a really cracking quality beer which I can never tire of.

500ml bottle.  copper pour with a big tan head that sticks around.  good looking brew.  muted but good aroma of toasted malts, caramel and light hops.  well balanced taste of toffee/caramel malts and candied fruits - backed up by a dry, spicey, orange peel finish (comes off as salty).  overall quality stuff.
Very nice!  Pours a reddish-brown with a creamy head.  Creamy mouth-feel with light carbonation.  Rich flavor yet well balanced with a dry hoppy finish.
Pours dark orange, with foamy, pale tan head. Sweet, Floral hop aroma. Honey malt and poundcake flavour, finishing with a pleasing dry touch

Bottle.  Poured dark waldhoney brown with lasting white head. Aroma of caramel and malt, very powerful.  Full malty flavour with a bit of nutmeg and honey.  Spicy fruity finish, with some nut.  Looks and tastes like an old ale should.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Acheté à la LCBO en format de 500ml et dégusté avec Glandine dans un verre de guinness. Apparence orange cuivré avec de léger dépôt en suspension et un emousse collante. Arômes dhoublon, de caramel, de pelure dorange et de poivre. Goût dhoublon, de caramel et la liste pourrais être longue car la bière est évolutive et présente un bon profil de vieillissement pour un bon 5 ans. Très bonne amertume et équilibre.
