Well I liked this beer, and it is certainly a nice alternative to the much more stern and alcoholic Vintage ale from Fullers

Best before 30/SEPT/02, Poured a reddish amber color with a large light tan head that had small creamy bubbles.  Aroma smelled was musty with a hint of light fruit and grape bubblegum. Dry hoppy flavor but as I worked my way down the glass it turned to a sweet alcohol taste to it. Given the reviews I had higher hopes.

after so many of these, it is becoming one of my favorites.  heard from the brewery will be on draft fall 03.  wow.  so beautiful, with notes of malt, hops, alcohol, but warming and smooth and great with food, chilled, room temp, an everyday beer of exceptional quality and pleasure.  yay!

Deep reddish brown with an off-white loose head. Aroma is malty with a little caramel and chocolate. Some alcohol also evident, but seems to be in balance with the rest of the beer. Immediate taste is an very deep sensation of bitter malt and fruit. Body is full and rounded with good carbonation. Deeply smooth and bitter finish. A warming, rich, satisfying beer with the advantages of bottle conditioning shining through. Wow! Sensationally good. Definitely a must try.
A beer with lots of aroma and flavor. Brown-reddish colored and an big head. Has a little bit of unpleasent "plastic"-flavor and aroma.

Bottled. Deep amber colour with plenty of conditioning on this fellow. Quite rustic looking. Big bottle to finish the night off with, thank god for Mr. Laidaw, taking half off me. At 6.3% it would have been a long way to the bottom of this final beer. It had been a big day for Pete, he taken his first jump from a plane this day, then assault with a hot Pakistani Curry and 6 different sorts of beer. I think he was chuffed.

A very nice copper coloration and BIG light tan head start off this brew.  The nose is a bit malty, with some sweetness and fruit notes as well.  Also quite nice, though it could be a bit stronger!  The flavor is very well balanced between the malt and sweetness, and has a nice little burst of  hoppiness in the finish.  In a style that never made much of an impression on me, this one certainly does...a very well made beer!

This beer rocks!
Slightly hazy, deep copper ale. Large, rocky, beige-colored head. Good lacework.
The nose is full of stuff: Raisins, light molasses, yeast (bread dough), tawny port and caramel.
The flavor matches the aroma. A medley of many rich things; caramel and molasses foremost. Fairly well-balanced.
Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Excellent finish! Lengthy, bittersweet and moderately alcoholic. Reminds me of a good scotch ale. A winner!

A vinous aniseed nose with a taste to match. This beer is very dry on the back palate but overall I think it lacks balance. The appearance is fine, with a great copper colour and good lace. It is a disappointment given the hype.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Cask ConditionedRed-amber color. Light malt aroma, they should work on it...Great taste, powerful, unexpected; big caramel and malt character, and strong hopping. Strong and long final as well.
Warming beer. Liquer-like. smooth orange flavors. I will age one longer next time and try again. An excellent brew.

Bottle conditioned 1pint 2.6 ounce brown bottle, back label says "best before Sept 02" had sitting since early Aug. 02 
Color is a nice hazy dark brown with a deep dark orangy glow. Finger high head of creamy foam, tannish in hue, big bubbles and lumpy from a vigorous pour, has some spotty lacing.
Smell is all caramel; sweet and candied toffee aroma and loads of caramel with notes of slight dark fruit and fresh bread. Hint of alcohol late and deep.
Taste is super smooth caramel malt, subdued in its subtle sweetness, balanced in with the perfect amount of earthy hop twinged bite and bitterness, and slightly drying. The hops start to make a bigger appearance and gets more noticeable as you go. 
Feel is solid medium bodied, slightly buttery and chewy, all soothingly smooth with a nice calming earthy dryness in the finish. Lending this barleywine to be incredibly delicious and drinkable, very enjoyable and head swimmingly soothing.
Made for a great night cap.... now I know I'll get some sleep.
Finishing the big bottle goes right to your head. Wow.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2004 I have now drunk two bottles of this at different times, I guess due to the nature of bottle conditioned beer they differed slightly. I was a bit dissopointed by the first, the second however was marvellous.
Certainly had a warming effect, was nice and smooth and just a hint of alcohol could be tasted, in addition there were earthy, nutty flavours. An excellent beer.
Subsequently re-tasted, it is a superb brew, my favourite from Fuller's, although I haven't tried the Vintage Ales.
A great English Strong Ale.
Reddish brown with a short lived white head.  Sour(Earthy?) aroma.  Initial dry malt burst of flavor, a subtle sour aftertaste. Smooth and a joy to drink.
Pours a glowing ruby color with a nice, thick off-white head. The aroma and flavor were full of nutty, malty sweet, roasty, woody, earthy tones. Nice refreshing feel.

Good sweet malty aroma -with a hint of nuts mixed in. Has a thin, mocha colored head which dissipates quickly but has good lacing. Pleasant bourbon like copper red appearance. Flavor - has a little bit of a dopplebok flavor to it. Slightly sweet but not cloying. Gets "chewier" as it warms - detect some nuttiness to it along with raisins and dates.  Excellent mouthfeel - just feels right.  Classic bottle. Overall - an excellent ale.

Holy crap!  This stuff is very aromaticVery spicy smelling.  Like a fruitcake.  Nice retaining head.  Has a fruitcake taste also..  Raisin, cherry, date, with a dash aof cinnimon.  Just a little too much alcahol present for the medium amount it has.  Very creamy

Has a great reddish/ruby color with some carbonation and a malted smell.  Taste is a great balance between the malts and hops finishing with a crisp bitterness.  Overall a great beer with excellent balance.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2007 Dark red.  Thick, large, light tan colored head.  Aromas of tobacco, coffee, strawberry, and some raisin.  Very rich and heavy.  Flavors of dark chocolate, raisins, nutmeg, and butter.  Aftertaste of sweet hops.  Outstanding beer.

Stellar, almost perfect. The only thing that I've liked better was Thames Welsh ESB, which is chewier.  Slightly smokey, raisin and prune, Maris Otter malt aroma which gives way to some toffee and vanilla as it warms. Ruddy brown beer, great bottle, seafoam-consistancy tan head.  Finely bittered -- this is the way to do hops, so that it compliments the beer without tasting like hop tea. Satin mouthfeel. Raisin, cream, bock/barleywine and ale flavors which leave toffee sweetness on your lips.
A great beer from Fuller. Amber brown color with creamy head. Aroma of malt and a little fruit. Goes down unbelievably smooth.Well balanced throughout with a hoppy finish. Very Impressive

Amber brown color and tan head. Malty and fruity aroma. Nice balance between malts and hops, a little sweet. Finish is somewhat dry but that's okay. Among Fullers better offerings. God how I love bottled conditioned ales (next to getting a great cask conditioned).
Redish color. Fine creamy head. Artificial flavor, kind of chemical. I don't know...one of us had a bad day, was it the beer or me?

Best English Ale I have eer had, very good Bottle Conditioning.  Fruity in taste, good creamy head with a hint of licorice giveing it a bitter sweet taste. I wish i would have bought more. Very Very Impressive. If you like the strong bitter sweet Ales from England this is one to try.

Really not so good. A chemical aroma.
Some chocolate and cocoa and I do NOT like that in a beer!
Red-brown coloured, small head. Aroma of roasted malts, liquorice, tar and port. Very, very bitter. Not my style, i wouldn't drink it again.

Clear red color, short mostly diminishing head. Aroma of red wine, brandy, burned malts. Burned malty taste, licorice, tar, even a bit sour acidic. Palate is dry, and bitter, bitter as can be! Horrifying bitterness combined with an acidic/alcoholic finish. Again, a heavily overrated english style.

Pours out a rich, amber color. Tan colored, huge, long-lasting head that slowly fades to a rich lace, and a creamy layer of
bubbles. Aromas right away of cherry brandy, peaches, kiwi fruit, strawberries, and apricots. This stuff is a veritable fruit bowl
in a bottle. Serving size - 18.6 oz. brown bottle. Rich maltiness to it, with fruity esters galore. On the sweet side to me.
Surprizing hops bite at the finish of it. Goes down smoothly. Well balanced, superbly crafted English ale. Hard to find in my
area, but worth the hunt. All in all, a really good example of brewing.

Beautiful deep red color, cloudy, with a very large, foamy off-white head. The aroma is one of the best I've ever enjoyed. Caramel, creamy, sweet, some plum and dates notes. The flavor does not quite live up to the aroma. The caramel is present, slightly sweet, but it seems a bit watered down. Still, quite a good brew.

Great big head, lovely color, somewhat dry, woody, spicy, citrus like in the bitterness. Been having a hard time finding it around here on the last search. Should I have stocked more bottles? Just afraid that they don't seem to cellar too long. When they get very old they tend to get "excitable" upon opening.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 An extremely foamy head on this brew.Good amber color.Fruity aroma and very smooth.Great lacing!Has an aftertaste to it after it gets a little warm, but this one I like.I definitely would drink this brew again and again and again!
Re-Rate:Bottle. Poured a medium sized vanilla fizzy head that had poor retention, fast rising carbonation, spotty amounts of lacing, and an orange  hue with a golden tint. The aroma was fruity, hoppy, sweet, malty, caramel, alcohol, and rich. The flavor was hoppy, caramel, malty, fruity, and the ABV came through although not overpowering. The mouthfeel was mostly smooth with a tinglyness and the body was light-medium. A well balanced beer with a warming sensation as it warmed up, worthy of a try, and a beer I will drink again if it comes my way.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 Highly invigorated light brown head of fine bubbles that left behind a nice lacing on the pour. It has a transparent dark amber brown body. Malty aroma mixed with hops. It has a fizzy taste of hops and nutmeg flavor. Very rambunctious! Went down smoothly

Dark amber body with smaller and bubbly tan head.  Good lacing.  Aroma consists of fruit (cherry, apricots) and roasted malts.  Flavour is a beautiful mix of fruit, roasty toasy malts and spices.  A great mix of taste without having either the typical citrus, chocolate or coffee.  Finish is dry and fruity with a hoppy bite.  A superbly crafted ale.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2003 Mr Kelly wouldn't give me a pay rise so I had to scum a shot glass from my beer buddy. Nectarine and Brandy dominates with a finish that leaves you in a sticky mess on the floor with half an attempt to cross your legs. Hops could be a little harsher...

Finished oak color with a medium creamy white lasting head.  Aroma of bread, molasses, roasted malt with some fruit( pears?) and alcohol.  Malt taste with some hop bite toward the back of the tongue.  Smooth, pleasant mouthfeel, somewhat chewy, alcohol is noticable in taste and feel.
Garnet in color with a nice foamy head. Complex taste of caramel malt, spices, and some fruitiness toward the finish, very nice
Thick, foamy head, rich pomegranate in color. Fruity, some spiciness, with a strong hops flavor in the aftertaste. Good, but I wasn't blown away, and because of the price I doubt I'll buy it again.
Very nice deep dark amber beer with a nice fine head.  Good fruit and heady malt aroma.  Nice hops with some happy tang on the finish.  Very good mouthfeel.
Bottle Conditioned, 2 years. Rich dark amber with thin head. Fruit, malt and port on the nose follows with a rich fruity body and quick drying hops. Great condition, lovely and smooth.
Lots of very tiny bubbles, ddark amber body.  Complex malt underlies the ripe fruits and spices.  Nice toasted dry barley flavor, lots of ripe fruits.  Great balance, smooth mouthfeel.
Wonderful burnt malty chocolatey taste very much like a stout. Strong UK ale at 6.3%

A classic!  Amber, maybe brownish in color, perfect looking beer.  Malty, subtle spice flavor, I know they are there,but I be damned if I could tell you what they are.  Somewhat fruity finish, it's an excellent beer people!

A very good beer, but not the best in the Fullers lineup.  My sampling was of unknown age, but this beer should survive a few years and it could not have been more than 2-3 years old.  Poured lightly hazy red-amber with a dense khaki head.  Rich raisiny/fig aroma, not much hop aroma (herbal).  Nicely balanced palate, its lightly sweet with caramel and raisin notes, followed by an herbal cough drop finish, which was surprisingly dry, with a light lingering bitterness.  Mouthfeel was lightly tingly from the carbonation.

Pretty strong hop  presence.  Some detectable maltiness.  Small head on a brown body.  Watery mouthfeel, and low, but persistant carbo.  Alcohol more noticable than many other ales that are significantly higher ABV.  Not bad, but I'll stick to Old Peculier

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2007 Dark amber/light brown color. Modest light tan head. Hops and malt aroma with hint of alcohol (like a cognac) and dark fruits. Early roast barley/coffee quickly followed by strong hops, then a warm alcohol finish (again, like a cognac).

Dark, copper-amber color.  There was little carbonation.  The head sticks around for quite a while.  It's rocky and tan.  Full, hoppy aroma.  A tasty beer.  Smooth drinking, good mouthfeel.  As far as my experience tells me, this is a good representation of the style.  I think I may keep some of this on hand at my house as a study beer or something.  Furthermore, the fact that's it's bottle-conditioned, means that it has the potential for extended shelf life.  Hats off to Fullers, once again.
clear deep orangish/amber with a thin almond colored head. aroma is malty bready and slightl caramel. flavor is buttery toffee. can detect the alcohol a tiny bit. has a woody finish and aftertaste.
Working with a slightly stopped up nose I didn't detect much aroma. Wonderful golden color and great taste. It left a with an earthy finish

Aromas of flowers, sugar, light fruit, alcohol and cake.  Aroma is almost too strong too sweet.  Mild on the tongue at first, with a more harsh finish, but not overwhelming.  Can't pick out any strong flavors, just a nice sweet, syrupy sense with this one.
This amber ale has a medium white head. The nose has richly caramely maltiness with flowery and toasty elements. The palate is medium with caramel and some light hops on the finish.

Pours deep amber/brown with medium tight beige head. Floral hop aromas, along with coffee and caramel. Very floral taste, with hints of roasted coffee.. chocolate.. caramel. Sweet malt well balanced by hops and roasted grains. Lovely and smooth too :)

I've tried quite a few ESAs, and I really wasn't that impressed by this one. The flavor and aroma were dominated by honey and assorted floral accents. Over and over again I thought about the smell and flavor of dandelions. Finish was plenty bitter but unfortunately there was little hop flavor to speak of. Typical English malt profile: smooth, creamy, toffee-like, etc., but not enough to enthrall me. Definitely not Fuller's best.
A fairly standard ale. I wish it was as complex as the commmercial description said, I'd have enjoyed the cake/spice aspects.

Dark clear amber coloured. Low carbonation. Medium head. Distinct chocolate aroma. Lots of coffee, toffee and hints of alcohol in the flavour. Medium bitterness in the end with a touch of coffee and alcahol. Very nice beer.

My trip through the nicer Fullers products continues. Lovely bronze color with a tan and lasting head. Good lacings, very lacy. Not very big in the nose but very big and malty in the mouth. The hops are there bittering but not really aromatic. Not as biscuit-ish and bread like as the Ale and the Vintage but big malty flavors, nonethe less. The finish is well balanced between the malt and the bitter.
Bottled, delightfully fruity nose, hints of strawberries, no head, dark/tawny colour, hints of malt and fruitcake in the taste, thouroughly pleasant aftertaste.

Brilliant dark copper color with a lasting two finger beige head. Nice lace. Dry caramal and malt nose that tend to get fruitier as it warms. Smooth feel with deep malt flavors. Toasty, with a light citric hops finish.  A very satisfying ale.

Dark amberish-copper color, nice lacy off-white head, sweet & malty balanced aroma, full-bodied & nicely balanced, had some very heavy & complex flavors, a bit of a hoppy aftertaste but very smooth & drinkable

A dark copper body topped with a creamy tan head that doesnt go away this beer is pretty dang good!  the aroma has a hint of hops and lots of malty goodness.  the sweet end of the malt is caramelly both in the nose and in the mouth.  the hops shine through quite surprisingly well in both taste and bittering roles.  some fruity sweetness to finish off the tasting experience leaves me wanting more of this medium-full bodied delight.

Quite delicious. Aroma of light hops, caramel malt and biscuit. Poured a clear copper amber color with a thick beige, lasting head. Nice lacing. Caramel malt flavor with biscuit and a light bitter hop aftertaste. Very well balanced and smooth. Mouth coating caramel mouthfeel.

This beer has a fantastic amber color and a good head, though it disappears fast. The aroma is slightly fruity. And the flavor is fantastic with hints of oranges and a slight sweetness ending of with a fantastic bitterness from a great sort of hop. Nothing less than a fantastic beer.

Dark amber, almost ruby in color.  Medium sized tan head, slowly diminishing to a strong lacing.  Very light, tiny-bubbled carbonation.  Aroma is strongly sweet and doughy - almost like a cookie dough.  Lighter aroma from fruits (raisin, grape, apple), and caramel.  Flavor is malty sweet, some of the same cookie dough from the aroma, and light caramel tones in the back.  Thick and chewy on the tongue.
Mild yeasty caramel aroma.Softning medium hop bitterness.Mellowed mild flavors of fruity chocolate malt.

Dark red and brown color with perfect head on the pour. Lacing was plentiful and the head stayed with me for the whole ride. Smells very rich and complex. A well brewed beer in its own right for sure. Flavors are very distinct. On this one I got a carmel/fruit taste along with a sweet yeast aftertaste. Goes down very smooth, coats your mouth like a stout by flies down your throat like a pale. Overall a excitingly tasty beer, obviously the best english strong ale Ive ever had.

Pours a dark amber/red color with a medium sized white head that lingers and leaves nice lacings on the glass. Nice fruity malt aroma. Very rich and fruity taste. I really enjoyed this beer. Another great Fullers concoction.

Absolutely top notch! Pours with a good head, the liquid is deeply red in colour.  This is one to be savoured.  The balance is Just how I like it, not too much hoppy bitterness and plenty of malt.  So overall a perfectly balanced ale with dry, fruity finish.  I must put one away and let I develop fully....
This is the top of the line beer for Fullers. From the almost lacy head to the rich, deep reddish hue. The balance between the flavors, hops and malt is exquisite. I love this brew.

Rerate: Looks amazing - a beautiful mahougony. Just a top beer.

Original:Amazing beer which was much more bitter last time I tried it than I had remembered. Hops, smokeiness and dried fruit in taste.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2010 One of the most beautiful beers Ive ever seen. Deep, deep red color. Thick, slightly reddish head leaves sheets of lace for the whole glass. Fruity malt aroma. Front is slightly sweet. Flavors of apple, caramel, and alcohol become more pronounced as the beer warms. Dry, slightly acidic finish. Full flavored, well balanced, and delicious.
Great aged ale.  Very similar to the 1999 vintage ale in my opinion, but not as complex or robust (more basic and not developed as fully).  Laced with a little spice, nice balance of hops with malt.
Rich bronze color. Nice citrus aroma with a smooth rummy body.  Wonderful toasty malt flavor with hints of chocolate. A clean, dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2003 I found one of these in a gas station that said "best before sept. 2002" on it.  By far the best 1845 I've had.  Great appearance with big tan head.  Smells of dark fruit and spices.  Very malty with little hop presence, but noticeable toasted flavors and caramel, while spices and fruit flavors dominate the finish.
Nice amber ale. Slightly bock-like. This was an exellent brew. Fruity and spicy
Sweet malty aroma and puffy white head.  Light brown body tastes of caramel malt and goldings hops.  Silky palate and a great toasty finish.  A fine British Ale!
Just like the description.  Good stuff!

Earthy caramel nose.  Deep ruby hue.  Sticky off white head.  Light malts first, caramel, earthy, medium bodied, crisp and lingering bitter finish.  Very nice, very drinkable, and perfectly well rounded brew.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2005 A really nice beer with tantalizing complexity. Subtle hops and very nicely balanced with fruity malt and spice flavors. Despite bottle-conditioning and above average ABV, freshness is crucial with this one. A fresh bottle is exquisite. Ive had some older bottles that were lackluster.

Re rate. Saved a bottle from the last time I sampled this beer to see if aging improved it and happily it did. Spicy golding hops with a background of nuts in the nose, hop grain and biscuits in the mouth and a chalky, hoppily bitter finish with a suggestion of tangerine.
Previous rating only 3.4, age it for a year or two.
Nice brown color with a very smooth carmel-fruit taste. An excellent ale, one of the best I have ever tasted.
THe aroma is rich with fruits, hops and malts, the color is a nice brown color with a very light tan head.  Very malty flavor with a slight hop finish.  Very, Very good stuff

Best British ale I have found so far.  Beautiful mahogany color like a DFH raison detre, but not quite as sweet and a bit hoppier.  Hops seemed to dominate both malt and sweetness, and to hide some of the spices that I knew were hiding in there.  Still, a great brew.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2008 Firm, lasting head. Aroma and taste both have malt, raisin and licorice. Good lacing. Alcohol burn. Some roasted malt and oak. Great strong ale.

Cask: dark brown color. Marmalade fruit and some earthy hops in the aroma. Red fruit jam, bitter cookies and earthy, citric and flowery hops in the flavor. Malty, slightly alcoholic, full bodied. A firm peppery hopbitterness in the aftertaste. Delicious!

Great strong ale.

Liked the creamy head the most.

Mahogany color. Medium long-lasting head. Fruity caramel aroma. Slight alcohol aroma. Some hops in the nose. Wonderful aromatic blend. Surprisingly quite bitter. Very malty. Slight roasted flavor. Strong caramel and toffee flavors. The bitterness and roast seem a little out of balance but good nonetheless. Creamy. Full bodied. A very nice English Strong Ale!
The best thing about this beer is the finish; dry hoppiness and a slight, malty sweetness.  Great appearance and smooth going down the old gullet.  Good stuff.

Actually, Im quite impressed.  This is very dry beer, somewhat like a good merlot wine.  It is very smooth and very nice-looking: bright red body and thick white head.  This is a sipping beer to go with a good steak.
A bottle of this and Im a happy man.  Perfect malty sweetness and a perfect bitter hop finish.  Also a classy bottle.
jesus, this brew has some head, and its in no hurry, great brew.
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2003 Strong honey aroma, smells a little like mead. Huge head that stuck around for a while. Found some bottles in a gas station that were aged (no one buys them). Very fruity.

Pours a lovely orange-amber with a generous pocked head and fine webbed lace...Aroma is rich, estery, lightly sweet, a bit like a cream sherry...The flavor is dry, slightly roasty, with well-bittered hoppiness and trace sweetness adding comment. The flavors are layered and have great interplay...Carbonation is suitably light...Body is full; it is quite smooth but with edges that bite a little---great mouthfeel! In sum, this is great drinking...Richness, complexity, harmony, substance---all here in ample measure...First rate!

Initially has the appearance of a raspberry ale though it takes on a more amberish hue. Nice cream head and highly carbonated as small bubbles cling all over the glass. For the first 10 minutes or so, the beer had a chlorinated taste/mouthfeel. After considerable warming, the qualities of this beer seem to unwind. Subtle honey malt fragrance and a light malt spicing in flavor (a tad skunky/mildewy) at first. This beer has a dryish finish and has the feel of a red ale/esb--I am not certain what English Strong Ale qualities this beer can be said to have.

A brown style ale that is superb to drink.  There is a good flavor of malt, but it is so smooth.  Started off doughy, but the hops came in on the back end to balance it out.  Im going to find another one of this.

Thick, creamy, and complex!  Dark unpolished bronze color with a tall rocky head.  Nose is bready with hints of fruit and spice.  Rich mouthfull that let me stroll through the ingredient list.  Superb caramel maltiness gives way to soft cookie dough, then the bitter end leaves you with hints of hops and spices.  A wonderful experience!

Dark and hoppy against a backdrop of malt.  Great aroma.  More refined than most, if not all, American strong ales.  Shows its breeding.  Too bad it is fighting with the strong onions on the hamburger I just had, right now its a draw but the ale should win in the end.

great ale,
murky bronze colour,  fruits and floral hops in the aroma.
taste strikes a balance between rich malt and bitter  floral hops, flavor hasa birned fruit and herbal quality.
I like to think of it asa genteel british arrogant bastard.

Nice and rich redness in the color. Bready and yeasty nose. Cool and easy-flowing mouthfeel quickly turns to a rich and creamy thickness. Has a nice malty bitterness about it. The texture seems to solidify in your mouth! Seriously, take some in, let it sit on your tongue for sec, and then realize what Im talking about. It really does thicken with time! Fresh yeast flavors linger about. This beer is super malty with a rich bitterness in the finish. Toasted caramel nuances exude. Some soft and bitter, low-note hops are ever present.

This is a full-bodied, GREAT tasting beer.  Excellent, I will definitely be buying more of this.  

Pours semi-cloudy, a hazy amber color with a thin head.  Couldnt peg the flavor, but know that it has a nice full finish with staying power.
Malty, spicey aroma.  Outstnding flavor of malt, fruit and spiciness, with a hint of whiskey.  Warm sensation from the alcohol.  Well balanced bitterness.

Copper color, large head. A medium bodied ale. Rich smooth malts, with a sharp biting hoppyness. Mellow flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry and clean. Aftertaste is sharp and malty, slightly bitter. Nice mild ale

Clear dark amber with a thin reddish tan head.  Malty, sweet, caramel, aroma.  Toasty, bitter, tea like, slightly astringent, slightly spicy taste.  The hint of sweetness is well balanced with a bitter hoppiness.  Refined and very tasty.  Kind of like an Arrogant Bastard lite.

A nice red beer with a frothy white head.  Aroma is of fresh wheat and sweet popcorn.  A nice crispness comes from the hops, which are perhaps a bit overpowering.  Nevertheless, this one easy drinking beer.

Certainly not an every day ale but awesome nevertheless. Hazy brownish-orange with a healthy and pleasing dose of hops. Chocolate and spices abound on the nose. Similar sensations in the flavor with a rather dry finish. Still one of my favorites.

Certainly a rich and spicy brew, full bodied and perfectly carbonated, however, I cant say Im a big fan of the flavour make up. The spicy flavours from the hops and yeast are not balanced by the rather weak malt.

Deep clear amber.  Huge head with a soft pour. Nose doesnt seem all that complex to me.  Dark roasted malts and some faint hops.  Palate seems to be a little chalky.  It seems to be better overall than its individual traits. Still I was expecting better from Fullers.

A bit weak for all the build up, but very good reguardless. The overt hoppiness is balanced by a very nice malt presence.  Mellow maltiness blends into a smoky finish that is really tasty.  It takes a bit more appreciation and attention to detail to really dig this strong ale, if compared with an American strong ale it seems almost weak, but this is still very good in its own right.

I cannot do this one justice with words, so I will para phrase Gusler, With whom I agree on this one: Deep garnet color,  Creamy, beige head. Start is malt sweet, the middle is medium to full, the finish is Hop heaven, dry, acidic
                and moderate carbonation tops off this Most Excellent strong English Ale.
One word: Yum.
Pretty complex beer. Not the best though. Very bitter.
A very warm and spicy beer with a long bitter aftertaste. I drank this in the sun on a hot Danish summerday (almost 25 celsius). Probably not the best time to try it.
Nice color, full Malty taste. I liked the Vintage 2000 Ale better, but is a good beer,I think Ill put a few bottles away and try them again.

Fullers makes some awesome brews, and this is no exception.  The malts rule here, with a lovely aroma, color and flavor all excellent.  A wonderful example of the style.  If you like this, i recommend trying Portland Benchmark Old Ale, made by MacTarnahans Brewing in Portland Oregon.  It is a little known beer, definately the best thing they make, and i highly recommend it.  Hard to find, but worth the hunt.  Try Belmont Station or Liquid Solutions, both will ship beer, and are located in Portland.

Such a perfect example of the style. I agree with Kevin that the malt shines here, without as much of the thick sweetness as in the Vintage 1999. Here the drawback might be the palate is a tad thin. Wonderful long lingering malty finish, alcohol burns so slightly, aroma is heaven with a slice of spiced rum fruitcake. Real real good. Beautiful presentation.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Tasted to me a slightly reigned in version of the vintage ales.  Great nutty maltiness without being sweet in the finish.  Hops are there in the background, but the malt is definitely the star here and how it shines...
delicious, thick, beautiful color, nice hops, complex flavors blended so well together. how could it get any better?
Great for the style, fruity aroma, sweet and tasty.

definitely taste the hops and alchohol on this one (although its not all that strong)... dark amber in color, medium to thick body... moderate malt flavor... surprisingly hoppy - more so than say Fullers ESB... nice spiciness on the finish... very warming - much like a winter ale... good stuff...
Pretty amber color with a wonderful bitter alcohol flavor.  Complex yet well balanced.
wonderful. nice bitter, faintly alcoholic flavor. strong finish, almost like a barleywine. nice carbonation. excellent long lasting mouthfeel.

Dark amber color with a off white lasting head with moderate lacing.  Nice balance of malt and hopps.  Complex.  A good example of an english strong ale.  This exceeded my expectations and will be on my repurchase list.
This beer is good all around.  It has a really long lasting aftertaste that is enjoyable to the end.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2006 A delightful brew.  Nearly perfect bitter hop/roasted malt balance.  Head is initially frothy.  Color is a deep amber hue.  Finish is fruity.  Definitely the best English Strong that I have ever had out of a bottle.

Wonderfully balanced with sweet maltiness and fruitcake aromas. It has a rich and full palate with a almost bitter sweet finish. This is not the type of beer that you can have anytime but it goes well at the end of a meal with dried fruits and cheese.
A very fine ale indeed. Rich and roasty with the sweetness and malty texture of a wee heavy without the inherent burnt flavor. Very smooth and one of the most well balanced beers I have tried.

Great pour, with decent head atop a lovely amber liquid.  Delicious malty aroma.  The caramel malts delight the taste buds, and hints of coffee and mild alcohol undertones complete the beer.  Very rich, stays comfortably on the tongue.

Fantastic aroma, reminiscent of pound cake, sweet potatoes, brown sugar, and cranberry sauce.  Creamy texture, complex, bittersweet malts, and oh so smooth.  A bit cloying when chilled, but at cellar temperature, the drying hop finish comes through nicely.  A stellar brew, just like London Porter (and I have a Vintage Ale 1999 stashed away!)

Pours a very dark amber color, with a slight malt flavor with elements of coffee.  Definate alcohol and coffee in the taste as well as malt and hops. Slightly bitter, but that is good for this style.  I found this to be a very drinkable beer. I hope to find other of Fullers products that hold up as well or better.
Amazingly good ale, with very strong woodsy malt flavor.  Nice coffee and carmel flavors and an excellent dark amber color
Powerful full complex malty woody taste.  Aftertaste keeps going for a long time.  The bottle that I had on 12/17/01 had a best before date of 5/12/02.
Standard English ale appearence with chocolate and coffee hints in the aroma and flavour.  The beer is good but is slightly over bitter for my taste at times.

Deep/dark amber-red color. Pours with big foamy head. Medium strength nose of sweet malt. Smooth flavors of semi-sweet malt, fig and honey - accompanied by some bitters. Very mild hopping. Smooth and crisp finish. Nice solid quality ale - a pleasure!
My favorite offering from Fullers (at least among those Ive tasted so far). Great looking in the glass and equally as great tasting.

Pours a nice dark amber color with a big, off white head. Great sweet, malty nose. Flavor is dominated by a dry, pleasant bitterness, complimenting a slightly fruity, roasty, sweet maltiness. Leaves a clean palate and a desire for more.
One of my favorite beers of all time.  Its amazing complex and rich.  There is nothing more I could ask for in a strong ale.
Typical English strong ale.  Try Olde Suffolk instead.  A strong malt bite hits you as you drink this beer.  It is a solid offering, as is everything from Fullers.

Very interesting beer. More subtle, I think, than the ESB. Where the ESB hits you with its full chewy maltiness, the maltiness in this beer is more subdued and youre actually slammed by the bitterness the first couple of sips. As you get used to the bitterness, youll start to notice the sweet maltiness (although this is still more subdued than in the ESB) A little later especially after the beer warms up, youll start to notice some toffee notes starting to mix with the maltiness and slightly citric bitterness. I even noticed the occasional slight hint of banana, but Im not sure if I wasnt just tasting things.

Deep chestnut color, slightly hazy with a nice head and decent lace. Bready,malt nose with hints of spice and fruit. Massive bready flavors,thin to medium bodied,some spicyness detected (nutmeg). Finishes dry, bitter, and acidic, oversteps its bounds in this aspect IMHO. A decent pint but not as good as I was expecting but by all means not one to pass up.
Bottle.  A nice head that lasted the entire glass.  Somewhat dry with a quick finish.  A classic british style beer - very enjoyable.

This stuff has the perfect deep coppery red color that an English ale should have. The flavor is beautifully nutty, with just the right touch of spice and sourness to give it a distinctive character. The finish is on the dry side, with the alcohol showing through just a little for warmth.   A wonderful ale.

While this is a beautiful looking beer, a nice reddish-brown, caramel color with a diminishing head, immediately there is a bitter malt bite, very dry and acidic, but it softens and slightly sweetens with successive sips, still maintaining that dry bitter finish.
Not as good as i remeber, quite malty and sticky, nice fruitcake taste, with a decent sticky bitterness, i dont like it as much as i used to.
Not as impressive as it sounds, rather dry and not overly complex.  The fullers vintage is a much better choice for a bottle conditioned ale.

The commerical description is fairly good though it makes this beer sound slightly more exciting than it is. A bit more refined than Fullers London Pride; bolder and more hearty but otherwise similar.

Generous head of large bubbles, deep red color.  Aroma is spicy with noticeable fruit--I placed it as raspberries, but others might disagree.  Strong alcohol, sweetness, and bitter finish make this better accompanied by food, but nice complex of flavors (nuts, caramel, fruit) make it enjoyable on its own.  Excellent beer.
Nice sweet nutty aroma, some alcohol evident.  Good flavour, malty and buttery.  Finish a bit bitter for my liking.
This is a damn good beer. Malty, toffee spicy aroma.  Flavor is full initially sweet, then hints of toffee and malt, as it becomes more bitter and finishes off with a nice bite.  Delicious.
Good, complex ale, but too strong for my likeing.
nice fully bodied aroma, dark carmel color, wonderful balance of sweet texture and hoppy after taste

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2012 Bottle (500mL, BB Jun 2012). Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (apricot), with a strong note of cardboard. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, papery. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation.

Wow, still 6 months away from their BB date and already this is oxidized to hell (bought from cold storage too).  Not much else in the nose besides the cardboard even.  Dead in the mouth.  Truly awful.  I thought this used to be good???
Huge head with staying power.  deep amber in color.  Very full in taste - Hoppy, malty, and fruity all in one!  I really like this style. Highly carbonated.  Great beer.
A good reddish gold looking beer with a nice full head and aroma with faint hops and something whiskyish. Definitely worth trying again, and maybe again...
A good bitter.

Deep garnet in color, the head is creamy and beige, the lace covers the glass well. Nose is malt, caramel, slightly sweet. Start is malt sweet, the middle is medium to full, the finish is Hop heaven, dry, acidic and moderate carbonation tops off this Most Excellent strong English Ale.

Had a pint bottle of this at The Old Bag of Nails in Upper Arlington.  This brew pours a ruddy orange.  The titanic off white rocky head has amazing lacing.  The head that ate Ohio was still occupying the space 3/4 the way up the pint glass when I downed my last gulp - outstanding!  The moderate nose is balanced and complex with herb, spice, and flower, combined with spruce and earth.  Some cask wood was also evident.  The flavor is sweet, warm, spicy with a toasty quality and a long rich and bitter finish.  The medium to full body is creamy, dry and smooth with a light alcoholic and astringent finish.  A very nice prelude to my Fish and Chips dinner.

Very nice.  Strong but not overpowering fruity aroma, reddish-brown with very impressive head retention.  Caramel, nutty, malty flavor in the beginning with a pleasant fruity, hoppy finish.  Ill be buying this one again later.
Reddish brown color with fruity aroma. Taste has a bite at the end but very nice flavor. Excellent hops but not as good as the ESB.

Fruity malty aroma, beautiful ruby body with short-lived beige head. Big malt flavour quickly followed by huge hop bitterness. Excellent, chose this Celebration Ale to bring up my ton and Im glad I did.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2004 Re-rate.  I must have been drunk the first time...Syrupy and heavy - like a Scottish heavy.  Sweet malts are complemented by a bitter burnt toffee flavour.  Spicy hops are present that give this beer a warming feeling - and the alcohol helps.

Pours a beautiful reddish-brown  pint w. a big rocky head. Hops dominate aroma w. some caramel/coffee. Nicely rounded flavor - very well balanced w. sweet maltiness up front and a great hop finish. A classic.

This is a 6.3% alcohol by volume bottle conditioned ale that pours with a dark amber color and a thick beige colored head. The nose is unusual and complex, with some dried citrus rind, coffee, sherry, and dry wood tones. The flavor is equally complex and impressive: a rich blend of roasted barley, toasted nut, caramel, hops, coffee with woody flavors (yes: woody flavors). Finish is warm and bitter, a little on the dry side but very, very satisfying. It is difficult to refrain from chugging this ale. It is slightly sweet, bitter, and very rich in flavor.
An excellent drink. Nice, strong flavours, but not overpowered due to its high alc. content.
nice dark amber colour with creamy head, malty aroma, floury taste

Very vegetable: hops and vinegary kraut lashing a big biscuit body.  There are some finer, spicy notes as well, and the thing blazes beautifuly red with a bold head topping it off nicely, but that initial vegetable essence lingers into the aftertaste and Im not altogether convinced.
Nice pineapple aroma, tart taste.  The thickest head I have ever seen on a beer!
Crazy thick head. Tart, syrupy taste similar to Arrogant Bastard but with less bite. Sweet aroma. Very good!
A pretty good brew indeed.
aNOTHER GOOD fULLERS BEER. gOOD TASTING BEER BUT THEIR IS SOMETHING MISSING. i JUST DONT KNOW WHERE IT MIGHT BE!
Great beer!  Beautiful head.  Very complex yet it all came together and went down smooth.  Not as good as the ESB in my opinion.
Its another great Fullers Ale! Fullers is proof that god loves us and wants us to be happy!

I have yet to have a better beer than this from England. A British friend once remarked pretty good for a southern beer Very complex and chewy not too gassy like some other bottle conditioned beers.
Amber orange in colour with slight off-white head.  Yeasty, bready, malty, winey aroma with a similar flavour.  Also tasted butterscotch.  Fairly harsh.
A good beer that is much better poured than in the bottle.

Outstanding.  Man, what flavors in this one.  An ale with everything.  Pours to a very dark amber and a generous head.  Tons of lace, and a wonderful aroma.  Very fruity tasting with tons omalt.  However, with that said, the hops are right there with the malt to balance it out.  How does Fullers keep such balance in their beers?  Incredible.  There is so much flavor, its unreal.  The absolute opposite of a light beer.

OH MY GOD.  This has to be one of the best tasteing beers I have rated so far.  As soon as I saw the beautiful amber color slowly make its way into my glass, I knew it was going to be love.  Excellent beer.  If this is what all English Strong Ales taste like, then damn, I may have a new fav. Re-rate:  Still good, but I have found many more since then.
This brewery can do nothing wrong, another top ale.

Fruity aroma like the description states, much like fruitcake smothered in whiskey or brandy.  The taste is complex, with notes of candied fruit, chocolate, and spices.  Each sip I take I taste something I didnt taste before.  This was recommended to me by a store employee, and Im glad I tried it.  I really like the initial sweetness and bitter finish.  Definitely a keeper, but a little expensive to drink often.
Another good English beer from a great brewery.
A solid brew by Fullers.  Smooth as a bottle conditioned beer should be.  A good hearty beer for a cold winter evening.  The story behind the hops makes it even better.
Hooray for Fullers!

A wonderful thing. This is the only brewery I ever toured in England and I dont recall this being one of the offerings. I have been passing this one up for a long time and i am sorry I have. Wholy yeasty but not offensive. Beneath is a a plathora of flovours; hops, rosted malt and dried cherry. Love it.
Roasty caramel aroma and flavor with some maltiness and hop notes. Some initial yeastiness that is on the overwhelming side, but this subsides with warmth. Nice syrupy caramel taste.

Once the initial yeastiness is overcome, a hoppy, roasty beer emerges.  Roasted barley and apple aroma is hampered by the yeastiness, while the nutty, apple, raspberry, tea, hops, and roasted caramel flavor hides the yeast better. Dark amber with a long head and dry, hoppy finish, the yeast presence sabotages what otherwise is an excellent brew.
nice hops

Well...if I could only choose one beer to drink,
this would be the one! I find it amazing and cant say
one thing bad about it.
Hop aroma and flavor is the dominant element with a well-developed smooth and creamy feel. Its hardy and full flavored without anything simple hammering at a single point.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2004 yet another rerate of this beer. glowing amber-red, almost pink, with a creamy frothy head. fruit + toffee + goldings smells. taste starts with full, juicy, sweet, buttered-toast malt, then gradually dries up and becomes peppery and bitter, and maybe a bit medicinal. lingering taste of fruitcake with heaps of orange peel. this has a lot of class.
rotten fruit and chocolate. very strong taste for an english beer. shame its so pricey but well worth a taste
This was a good looking tasteful brew.  Im enjoying fullers more & more.
Sharp syrup-mincemeat aroma is very inviting. Sort of a Scottish Ale Lite that works well. Nice flavor explosion in the mouth.
A great ale with pear overtones; a little hoppier than I normally like, but more than made up for by the big malt and yeast.  Good cold, but more flavor released when warmer.

Not as good as some  of the other Fullers range, a rather smokey taste, not really unpleasant, but something I think id have to get used too...

Maybe ill cellar some and try it after a year....
I like strong ales, and this a damn fine ale. Maybe a little yeasty for some, but not for me. Ive heard that they cellar very nicely, and I think ill start building my cache today.
Yummy. These are cellar-able and I have had bottles that were a year old and they mellow out nicely. A true hidden gem.
English bottle-conditioned Strong Ale. Its what an English Strong Ale should tast like.
Outstanding English ale; nose is rather faint, but pleasing in its spiciness, which is echoed in the hints of cinnamon, cardamom, nutmeg in the flavor.  Gorgeous head and color, nice finish.
A knock-out. Drinking the pint-plus bottle of Fullers 1845 is like reading a great short story -- complexity, layers upon layers, gets better and better as it goes along.

This was a very good beer aside from one annoying fact. Subtle but I felt like I was drinking brandy or something. Could smell it and taste it though the more i drank, the less I noticed it. Otherwise, this is a nice deep flavorful beer.
Superb.
VERY SMOOTH DRINKING ALE I WILL TRY THIS AGAIN.
I really enjoyed this. Great malty flavor with some fruit. Excellant beer.
Excellent complex flavor and aroma, typified by yeast, fruit, with dry bitter finish. Especially complex for an English ale.

Im slowly warming up to English ales, due to fantastic brews like this example of an English Strong Ale.   Aroma and flavor is of warm bread, with some nuttiness and fruit coming through, finishing with a nice long, dry, roasty taste/feel.  Highly recommended.
Very low body, when alls said and done though, quite good.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2007 500ml bottle.  Richly toffeeish, toasty malt aroma, sweet and lightly herbal, with tinges of spice, golden raisin, apricot, caramel, dried flowers  and a faint nuttiness.  Deep red-orange color, lightly hazy, with a lasting, creamy, off-white head leaving a fine pattern of lace.  Flavor is predominantly malty, prominent dark brown sugar and toasted grain bread combine with suggestions of date, anise, citrus and wood, seeing a late influx of gentle, spicy bitterness and hop flavor.  Smooth and finely effervescent palate, body is medium.  Quite flavorful and nicely balanced.
nice amber color and a thick head.  low in body as suspected
Impressive body and flavor, I am a big fan of bottle conditioned beers, and this is one of the finest Ive tasted.

A very full bodied and complex, delicious English Strong Ale. Fullers ESB is a classic, but I think 1845 is even better. Very sweet and fruity, but some nice reserved hops appear in mid-palate and finish. World-class!
Thick head, (you can write your name in it). Rich, full-bodied taste. Sweet, fruity aroma. A favorite in my book.
A very rich, full bodied flavor.  I enjoyed this with a dessert.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2005 Attractive reddish-amber colour with a light tan head.  It has a toasty aroma with a hint of caramel, yeasty earthiness and light goldings.  The flavour is fairly robust, leaning towards dry malt notes like toast, as well as earthy notes which I find contributed by both the hops and yeast.  Its an earthy, woody brew with some gentle but insistent bitterness.  The Fullers yeast comes to the fore here, more so than in any of their other beers.  Good, robust ale...perhaps not as good as when I first had it (as beer 999 back in 1998) but still solid.
